I found that extra annoying since i had to pause my install to have a conversation with my wife and the app kept its audio on.I do have a detached garage and that is why i have a wifi extender. The MyQ was installed no more than 10 feet from the wifi extender with unobstructed view to it. The app showed all of the signal bars. A full length of the power cord away from the garage opener to avoid interference. No LED lights anywhere near. The garage sensor in open position was about a feet away from the main unit.

An absolute pain to set up. If you expect ease in setup, you're in for a rude awakening.The hub failed multiple times just to connect to my network, and once it finally did connect, it would not connect to my door opener's motor at all, despite the fact that my opener is a chamberlain and is compatible according to the app. I followed the instructions to the letter, and the hub continued to fail to connect to my motor after over a dozen attempts.

It was very easy to install. I could create my account and test garage door with no issues. Then from app I invited my wife to share account. My wife created new account using the shared link, but she could not set-up device as it was again requesting to connect internet. When I did set up the device it was already connected to internet. I had to factory reset and set it again to get access to both of us.It worked nicely for a day. Today I opened and closed garage using app. Then my wife opened the garage door using wall mount unit, MyQ app shows garage door OPEN. She closed garage using keypad outside garage, garage door closed. But MyQ app still shows OPEN, after few min it displayed error closing door. I opened the garage again using app and closed using app, but app still shows closing error.

I ran across this device last year around Christmas when it was on sale.  I had been thinking about doing something like this with my garage doors because my neighbor and sometimes my parents need to get into our house when we're away.  I had this option years ago through a previous smart-home system that I replaced a while back.  We have keyless entry, but it's not always convenient to hand out codes or for friends and family to remember them.  With MyQ, we can open or close the door remotely.I also have a forgetful son who has left the door open by accident when heading out to school.  In combination with our Ring cameras, the MyQ app allows us to monitor these situations and to close the door remotely.
Summary:They may decide to charge you.

Had a terrible time getting it to connect to my wireless network. Finally found on their troubleshooting site that I had to turn off a function on my android phone. Several more hub resets and connection attemps it finally connected. Then wouldn't connect to the door sensor until many tries later. Then it wouldn't mate with the door opener. The learn button on the opener has an LED that goes on when it is in learn mode. It flashes when I train a remote to it. It never flashed when the hub was supposedly being trained to it. Great idea but terrible execution. Returning to Amazon.

Works as promised. I installed it in a couple minutes, and can control the doors with my phone.  My favorite parts are the Schedule, and the alerts.  I programmed my doors to shut at 9pm everyday.  This prevents leaving them open overnight, automatically.  I also set it to notify me if the doors are left open for more than 45 minutes.  The only con was during the install the wifi joining procedure was not real intuitive.  I was lucky enough to have had similar experience with another smart home automation product, and was able to use that experience to hook up this one correctly.  But without that experience a novice user would struggle or not be able to install this product.

I just got this installed and once set up it seems to work pretty well once set up, but setting it up was a hassle as it seemed finicky to pair with my overhead door standard drive 650. Here are a few of my lessons learned so far.1. The mounting location in your garage is extremely important, I originally mounted it about a foot from the opener and it struggled, then I turned it 180* like it suggested and it still struggled, then I had success just mounting it on the other side of the garage near my workbench, but when I tried to reprogram it later, it wasn't receiving the signals (I could tell by watching the light on my opener which flashes when it senses a signal during the programming process, it never blinked. After moving it around I noticed more and more activity). I ended up having success mounting it the full length of the power cord away which put it right in the middle of my two openers at the same distance.

If Amazon allowed less than one star, I would give it a 1/4 star.  This product look nice and the packaging looks nice.  But the hardware is hardly laughable.  I am by no means an IT professional, but I did grow up building computers and do my own IT trouble shooting and have heavy experience with tech troubleshooting and electronic repair.The setup is extremely unresponsive unless you have the router in the next room.  And by next room, I mean right by the receiver unit.  My iPhone reads full bars of WiFi reception when the unit can barely get a signal of 1 tiny bar of WiFi reception from my router.  Keep in mind, I have a $150 Linksys EA7500V2.  The router range is more than enough to reach the garage; it actually reaches to the street which is an easy 100 ft away.  Not the top of the line router, but a very good one for a basic household.  I was not able to get it connect to the router one time in the 2 hrs that I was fiddling with it.  All I got was a frustrating 2 hrs in the sauna of a garage here in the HOT August South Texas heat.  Unfortunately, I would not recommend this garage door opener hub to anybody.  Hell, I feel bad to try to sell this barely used to somebody else.  My fault for not doing my own research on the product before buying it.

The hardware is really good, and the app for this opener had been great since I started using it last year, In fact better than great.  I had found it to be very relyable and extremely useful. But since the update a few months ago it has been untrustworthy. You know the LAST thing I need; running home from a dog walk after getting caught in the rain with my puppy.  Finding out the app lost my password AGAIN and having to control a wild puppy IN THE RAIN while looking up a password just to open the freaking garage door. Then once a week my family calling me at work to open the garage door because the stupid app lost their SAVED password again for the 3 time that week.  Then getting home after a hard day at work to find mine did the same thing and having to look up the password before pulling into the garage.And thats when it loads,  I have had to uninstall and reinstall the app on 2 different phones just to get it to load after its update.

I like this garage opener from the stand point that it works well when using the MyQ app on my iPhone. It does not however work well with Alexa. For one there is no native integration, which should not be difficult to do at all. Additionally when using Alexa to try to control the garage door it assumes names like bay 1 and bay 2 which make no sense when I have only 1 garage door and 1 sensor, and then saying "open bay 1" doesn't do anything anyway. Additionally when closing the garage door through the app the base unit beeps and flashes a bright light which I really do not like. I wish that there was an option to turn it off through the app. While it is surely meant to be a safety feature the garage already has it's own safety sensors (infrared beam + pressure sensor), the noise and light can wake everyone up at night and I may not want to draw attention to myself and that my garage door is open (there was a recent car jacking in a nearby house garage when the garage door was open for example). I am looking forward to an app and/or firmware update to improve the Alexa integration and to control the sound/light so that the door works as smoothly as other smart locks and Alexa-enabled devices in my house. This is the only one that does not work well outside of the vendor's app. Besides that installation was very easy and opening and closing the garage door works reliably.

I think the videos in the app that walk you through the install steps took longer than the actual job of installing this.The only snag was that when joining my WiFi the app got stuck.  I re-started the wizard and followed the prompts to manually marry the unit to my account and I was in business.  The short version is that there is a hub that needs to go in the garage, in range of your WiFi and the garage door sensor.  The Garage door sensor is a little box the attaches to your garage door with included adhesive backed Velcro.

Unlike every other smart device I have purchased, this product is not DIRECTLY controlled by Google Assistant (even though Google Assistant is capable of controlling garage doors directly). Instead of asking Google to "close the garage door", you have to say "ok google ask myq to close the garage door". Then, it transfers you to a separate myq assistant (which is pretty inflexible) to actually carry out the task.Connecting the myQ assistant to Google was a huge pain and took a lot of work since the documentation in the myQ app was inaccurate.

The product works, I'll give it that.  But there are some gotchas.  Here is the first one.  You set it up via your smartphone.  Many devices do that.  But if you have a smartphone that will use EITHER WiFi or Celldata access, you must first turn off the Celldata access!  If you do not, your phone, while trying to get into the MyQ device, will constantly switch to the cell network trying to get an internet connection, and your install will fail.  The instructions do NOT tell you this.  Ya gotta be a guru to know that trick.Once past that, the install goes very well as long as you follow the instructions.  But there is an issue with guest access.  To do that your guest needs to install the MyQ app on their smartphone, which requires you rto have the serial number of the door opener available.  If you do not, you cannot complete the guest setup.  Remember to log that SN in a place where you can find it.

This garage door opener never worked right. I thought it would be nice to open the garage with Alexa, just to find out you can’t use it with Alexa, not even ifttt (unless you want to pay for their scam service). Sometimes it would tell me I had left my garage open, so I would try to close it from the app. It would say it failed and the app wouldn’t work until I operated it from home. Not helpful when you can’t leave work. Lo and behold, sometimes my garage had been left open but sometimes my garage was shut as it should have been when I drove all the way home in a panic and hurry. Result of a fake garage open warning. Even standing inside my garage, the app rarely worked to close the door. Luckily all these problems occurred so often in the first month that I was able to return it before I was stuck with the piece of junk. In the last month they have lowered the price of this thing nearly $30, having trouble selling? This is why! Nothing but issues.

Sometimes wi-fi in the garage is not as good as you need.  install went great.  door shut. everything was fine.  then door would not open.  nothing worked except the notify!  I tried pairing again. nothing. paring worked sometimes then did not. but door would not open or shut.  I opened the door with my normal remotes I got notified via myQ.  tried resets,  reinstalled nothing changed.  so when I had time I deleted everything.  reset completely twice.  reset the sensors twice.  and started over again moving an inside wi-fi extender closer to get a better wi-fi signal.  took cars out of garage to make sure they were not in the way.  and did the re install from the start (except for the hardware)  door opened as before.  so held my breath.  finished the install.  and hit the close button twice.  door closed.  yea!  nice to be able to open the door from a block away.. as sometime the car remotes don't open the door even when we in front of the garage door!!!!  yep.  so now amazon can deliver in the garage nice if it is raining.. they tend to leave stuff out in the rain!!  been looking for a low cost mobile app to open and close my garage door and it works.  just have to follow the install perfectly.  there are videos to trouble shoot. don't skip over anything.  my hub is 5 feet from my opener.  my sensor is on my left side of my door.  I did all tests to make sure it all worked.  and of course made sure my door opener was compatible before I ordered.  it is and is only 5 years old.  I would have given 5 star if there had been a little better instructions on resetting the sensors too. you have to reset them all not just the hub.  and if anything fails you have to start over completely.  yep.
I have had this installed for approximately 4 months now. I am now in the process of finding alternatives.Setup and install were fairly easy and took maybe 15 minutes.

I bought the unit looking at the reviews and was super excited to use my phone to monitor my garage door from anywhere. The product was easy to setup but failed to work every time. I did multiple resets and different tricks to make it work but in fact it messed up my garage door travel limits and it stopped responding to the wall garage door opener.  I had to spend couple of hours to fix it to work normally with the wired opener.When devices are dependent on wireless technology the reliability will become an issue, in  this case the remote uses WiFi and also Bluetooth communication, I am not sure if that caused complexity in terms of bad WiFi signal and or Bluetooth reception/interference issues.

This is easy to install, in principle. It installed very quickly but took about 25 tries to get paired with my opener. Moved onto door #2. 10 tries in or so door #1 starts going up. Then door 2 goes. Says pairing failed, but somehow it's now controlling both doors at the same time when you try to control door 1. It senses both doors are moving but doesn't realize it's controlling door 2 also. If door 1 is up and 2 is down, and you use the app to close door 1, door 2 goes up. So after an hour of screwing around, I set them both in monitor only mode and gave up for the night. Literally as I read on my phone for help, it alerts me that the door just went up. Sure enough, I check and both doors are now open. The app has somehow reverted to the previous state, before I put them both in monitor mode, and sent a signal to open the doors on it's own. WTF.

I like the fact I can tell if the door is open or closed at any time and open and close it remotely. What I don't like is the surprise you get when you try to integrate it into your home hub. They charge a monthly fee. What BS. Charge a little more for the unit if you need to, but this money grab of a monthly fee is ridiculous.While this won't make me return the item, (return shipping will cost a quarter of what I paid for it) I cannot and will not recommend this product nor purchase anything from Liftmaster/Chamberlain ever again.

The good; this works reliably and hooks up with a bunch of garage door motors giving you a "smart" garage (more on that later) in that you can set notifications of when your garage opens and most importantly open it with your phone.The bad; the "smart" integration is a joke. Is Chamberlain for real requiring a paid subscription so you can ask your google home or alexa to open the garage? Come on Chamberlain be better than that.

Update:  would give zero stars if I could. Bought to make sure my family was safe while I was away. Tonight at midnight it opened when the program is supposed to close it if it was open. I noticed the alert on my phone saying it closed. Went out to check it and lucky for us the local cops were outside writing a note to let us know our garage was open after midnight. So the very device I’m trusting to lower our risk is actually creating risk. I will try to return it or it will go in the trash as a lesson learned.Original review:

Not many products can make me angry enough to take the time to write a review, but well done Chaimberlin, you win the prize. I purchased this thinking it would integrate with Amazon Alexa, since it boasts compatibility with Amazon Key, but somehow they neglected to include Alexa support. It will link up with IFTTT, which might cause one to incorrectly assume that you just need to walk through a few more steps to get it working. However, using the IFTTT link you cannot open the garage door for some unknown reason, you can only close it. As well as do a few other arbitrary tasks that no one cares about. Oh and by the way, thats only AFTER paying for their ridiculous subscription to allow you to integrate the services. Now you can use alexa to tell IFTTT to close the garage door, but you cannot use it to set up automation to open the door when you get home for example. Nor are there any useful features in the MyQ app aside from maybe setting it on a schedule. Which might work for me if I got off work at a consistent time every day, but I don't want my garage door opening at a specific time that I predict I might get home, only to have it sit open for a couple of hrs because I had to work overtime.If you want to pay $50 to be able to remotely open and close your garage from the MyQ app on your phone, then this is for you. If you want to integrate it with your exiswting smarthome I would suggest looking into other options. It does say it integrates with Google Home which might be helpful, but as I don't have a google home I can't test it's usefulness.

Let me start with the cons: works great, easy setup, customer service was friendly on the phone when I called.Pros: the loud unnecessary repetitive warning sound that this product emanates is extremely unbearable, it's exhausting. Therefore, it's the only reason why I am returning it tomorrow. There is no way to shut it off (tried black electrical tape over the openings, but no success). The customer service rep told me that due to regulations, all models came with this undesireable sound, that starts about 10 seconds before the door closes, during closing, and at least 10 seconds after the door has closed completely. Forget about surprising your wife when coming home, or not waking up the baby.

MyQ garage door opener is a great tool to open and close your garage door using a smart technology. Gone are the days when you leave home and wonder if you have closed the garage door. The packaging and build of the product is quite nice. The main unit is light and use to connect using the myQ app. The wall mounting of the hub needed better instructions and mechanism - it took me more than 20 minutes to wall mount it. The wireless sensor is easy to connect to the app. Once the main device is connected to WiFi, you are in good control of your garage door from anywhere with internet access ( using the app).The app interface is very helpful; you can also review history and schedule opening and closing. You can allow 2 guests to use the app. You can also control via Google voice assistant which I have not tried yet.

After a couple of months of use and tweaking, I have pretty much given up on this product.  Initial installation went pretty well, other than taking about 3 hours to get it to connect to my opener so it would open and close the door.  I had to turn off all the garage lights and work in the dark to get the initial connection to work.  I would estimate the actual open/close function works around 40% of the time.  Otherwise, the controller will light up, but it won't open or close the door.  I decided not to return, as the sensor telling me the whether the door was open or closed worked well and that was helpful to me.  Well, over the last couple weeks (after the return window is closed), that function has decided to go wonky as well. I get notifications that the door was left open for an hour, when it is closed.  I have absolutely no confidence in looking at the app whether my garage door is actually closed or open like it says.  Love the idea of this product, and if it worked as intended all the time, I would love it.  It would be more understandable if the wifi coverage was weak in the garage area, but I do have a mesh wifi system in my house that has very strong coverage in the garage.  Left with a product that will occasionally allow me to open the garage door with my phone, and nothing else.  Very disappointed.

I do not have an Alexa so that is the reason for the low review of that. I wish there was a N/A option for that one.Installation of the hardware was easy enough, but setting up the app and configuration of the hub was not as easy. I am an IT storage professional, so very familiar with setting up hardware/software/appliances. I was not able to use my newer HTC cell phone to complete the setup. It kept having issues with WiFi. My older Google Nexus 6 worked like a charm. Good thing I had a second cell phone to use.

My wife and I purchased the MyQ Wireless & Wi-Fi Garage Hub to use with our iPhones. I started the initial setup while she was gone and everything seemed to be going OK until she got home.  She couldn't connect her iPhone to it through her own email account.  She had to use my email account.  She didn't understand why Chamberlain is dragging their feet on being able to set up the app using two different email accounts.  We can do it with our Arlo cameras.  The system seems to work pretty well.  There is a delay of one minute minimum to send a signal to our router so it can alert our iPhones so it is NOT instantaneous.  You need to go into NOTIFICATIONS (under the Chamberlain app) if you have an iPhone and your opener is Chamberlain to make sure your alerts are turned on.  The little box that gets stuck with Velcro to your garage door had a little rattling sound to it when shaken like something was broken and loose inside.  After a little thought, I'm pretty sure it is a "dangly" level that senses when the garage door is closed making the sensor vertical or when it is open making it horizontal.  Overall, we are happy with it, at least so far. Just an update since we have installed the MyQ. It works as advertised. I thought I would be alerted whenever the door was opened or closed and I am. However, it is NOT instantaneous. The lowest setting of notifications is 1 minute so the door has to be open or shut for one minute in order to be notified on my iPhone. One thing that I would like to see Chamberlain change is the HISTORY. I would like to be able to select the events that I want to delete. Instead, you must delete ALL of the history. Other than that, we are very happy with the item.

We purchased this product because we often left the home wondering if we forgot to close the garage (even though we almost always did) and wanted a way to check and close the garage remotely.This smart garage hub was extremely simple to install. I had to be a little creative in making sure it had power (see picture with short extension cord that now feeds both my opener and the myQ hub), but otherwise it was an easy as hanging a picture. The myQ app steps you through the process of adding it to your WiFi, pairing with the garage door sensor, and pairing with your garage. I chose this brand over some of the others (like

Purchased this opener to replace a more expensive one that was advertised with native Alexa Functionality.  That one wouldn't stay connected to Wifi even though I installed a dedicated access point in the garage for it.  And every time it lost connection, I had to reestablish it manually.  But that's another review.I'm giving this 5 stars because so far (2 weeks ish), the MyQ does what it claims to do well.  As far as the connection, if it's ever lost the wifi connection, the MyQ has no problem reestablishing it on it's own as it's always been available when I've opened the app.

This product has saved me so many trips from turning the car around to go check if I’ve closed the garage door. The app is user friendly and notifies you of when the garage door was Open/closed last.For install: Plan to reserve about 25-30 minutes of your time. When you open the box, instructions will walk you step by step through install and where to place the sensors and hub. There’s even videos to watch for further explanation. I think the hardest part was trying to identify which garage door motor unit we had and we had to go through set up a couple of times until we selected the right one (the color of the button was faded on our garage door motor and hard to determine which one it matched with in the app).  Make sure you don’t have any other Bluetooth devices around while trying to install, so you have a clear signal. If you don’t have a strong WiFi connection, you will have issues trying to set this up and use it in the future.

Overall, I do like this product.  For about $40, I can add wifi-enabled remote control from my smartphone.  Installation was a breeze -- it took about 10 minutes from start to finish slowly following the instructions and videos provided within the app that I had to download (in my case, from the Apple Appstore).  Instructions and videos were very, very clear.  The app required me to register for an account with my email address and a password to run the software -- my iphone automatically logged me into the app when I open it, but it would have been annoying if my phone didn't do that as the app only allows control of the garage door remote hub if the user is logged into his/her account.Once everything was installed, registered and logged in, the app displayed the status of my garage door ("open" or "closed"), and it allowed me to open or close the garage door with two taps:  one tap to change the status to an actual command button, and then a second tap to follow through with the open or close command.  The open action happened relatively quickly after the command; the close action was heralded with the hub flashing its light and beeping for several seconds to warn of the garage door closing before the door started to close.

I understood from the Amazon display that this was easily integrated into the Alexa environment. I was also led to believe that this would allow Amazon delivery inside my garage, thereby removing the temptation from porch pirates. Not true.  I also understood that this device would let me know when my garage door was opened. thinking that I could eliminate my own forgetfulness this would be a great device,  Not True!  So we are back to my original question and headline, Why did I buy this?  In fairness to the device, it does behave as designed. it does send out a notice when the garage door is opened and a signal when it is closed. Fair enough. Maybe I didn't think this out thoroughly enough before buying it.  It tells me when the garage door is opened, well duh, I just opened it so I could drive my car out.  Maybe I wanted something to tap me on the shoulder a few minutes later, maybe ten or fifteen asking me why the door was still opened.  Yeah, that's what I wanted.  Well it does not do that. It does not link to Amazon Alexa easily. You need to jump through a couple of hoops before that may happen and that is with a technology called ifttt which is short for "if this, than that" .  At that point in time I was not ready for what I thought were silly games to make something work and sent it back.  Since then, I am learning that ifttt can be used for all sorts of things with Alexa. That is up to you to discover. This review is only about this garage door opener / notification device.  Biggest complaint of all was the instructions, or lack thereof! In addition, once you found the instructions on the internet, possible that what you find is not totally correct.  Bottom line, a device that could be very useful brought to market by Chamberlain, known for their excellent garage door openers, half heartedly brought to market by a marketing team that apparently could care less. If I brought a product to market like that a  few years back I would be out on the street looking for a new job.

So far so good.  First off, the first one didn’t work (or we programmed it wrong) but Amazon sent a replacement and my husband was able to install it and get it working right away.  I guess I don’t understand why people are complaining about the cost.  There’s only a cost if you want to connect to Google Assistant or other Home automation apps.  Just use the app by itself.  It really does work great and you can set all different kinds of alerts.  I can’t tell you how many times I’ve returned home just to see if I closed the garage and I’m so excited to be able to look in the history and it says “Garage Door Closed at ...”  what a blessing!

Let me start by saying I was on the fence for months as to whether I should actually buy this Garage Door opener from MyQ.  The reviews on Amazon were very mixed and I wasn't too pleased that once I bought into this product, I would probably have to spend more.  I will talk about that in a moment.I actually decided to make a purchase during Prime Day when the cost of this item sold for about $20 less than it regularly does.  It seemed like an absolute bargain at that point.

To start off, I bought this for a steal with Amazon Warehouse at under $12. How could I go wrong? Amazon was great and the item was in like new condition as promised.On to the product itself.  I plugged it in and synced it with my garage. The process was cumbersome and not smooth. It was saying that it was not working with my garage, meanwhile it's closing and opening the garage door 🤣 Finally it figures out that it's connected and we're good to go.

The MyQ WiFi is easy to install and easy to operate, especially since they updated the App (I am using an iPhone). The first one I installed in my Florida home. It came handy after the hurricane when I needed repair people enter the garage but I was out of town. I simply opened the door with a click from my iPhone. They thought it was magic. It truly saved me lots of time and trouble organizing a friend who would come to the house and open the garage door for the repair team. In the meantime I have installed four MyQ on all my garage doors on my two homes. The App is very well designed. I can see all four garage doors on one screen. The open and closed status icons are animated and also show how long the doors have been open or closed. Very helpful with a second home. It works flawlessly and I can highly recommend the MyQ.
I have 2 of these hubs w/ sensor from Chamberlain.1 is associated with an Amazon Cloud Cam for Amazon Key.  Its integration is cool and works great with Key.

The unit is easy to install. One drawback can be access to a plug, depending on how the garage door opener is installed. The plug has one of those square transformers (not sure that is really what it is called) on it, so if mounting bars are closoe to the plug, it may make plugging it there difficult.It works fine. When closing the door, the light comes on on the unit, and it makes a fairly loud repeating beep sound, for a warning for anyone standing in the garage.

Thought we received a defective unit.There were no "real" instructions included, just a quick set-up guide, even though their videos said over and over to read and follow the "included" instructions--which were not included.

This is a slick device that allows you to open your garage door with your smartphone and check whether your door is open or closed from anywhere. It works great, but it was a BOOGER to install, and here's why:At a certain point in the installation, you look at the Learn button on your GDO and based upon it's color, you follow a certain procedure to get it to talk to this device. I was installing this on a Chamberlain/Liftmaster door, and the Learn button was sort of a faded orange, certainly not bright orange, but closer to orange than any of the other colors they listed. I must have insanely tried the Orange procedure at least 10 times, but it never worked.

I'm the tech/gadget junkie in my family and I am used to getting things to work.  I have spent hours on this product and never could get it to work correctly.  I've tried their tech support, only to wait days for an email response to receive the same email of instructions I already had via their app.  I tried their chat tech support.  Went through about 30 minutes of work to, you guessed it, to again be provided the same set of instructions I already had.  They then told me I needed to speak with another tech...great, let's do it....sorry, you'll need to call back on Monday when they are here.I've done the same steps over and over and it simply never pairs the hub with my door, and I know my door is compatible.

Nice product, i picked up 2 of these to mount in both my attached and detached garage.Comes with its own app.  A bit tedious to do setup through their app, you have to click each Icon that says, yes I have a ladder, yes i know my wifi password, probably 6 or 7 of those questions, and if you are having problems you are re-answering those questions over and over again.  It is also Still missing smartthings integration, so my garage doors are controlled through this other app.  Was also disappointed during setup that I was having so many problems with setup.  I would recommend that you do not mount ANY piece of the system until you have it completely set up.  Otherwise you will be up and down a ladder, and in the case of my detached garage which has a taller door, even the door sensor needed a ladder to get to.  And at least one of the steps is time sensitive.

Edit 2020 noticed my review was cut off.Opens your garage door during a tornado because it thinks it's open.  This isn't cool.  We setup 2 alerts.  One to at 9pm to alert us if it was open and another one at midnight to close if shut.  Tornado sirens went off at around 11:45 and or was very very windy.  I got my wife and kid and headed to the basement.  As we were settling down we heard the garage door open??? I had to go upstairs and close it because the app was useless.  The app said there was a malfunction and it thought the door was open.  The sensor was mounted properly and was within range of the box.  Called support and they blamed it on a dead battery and told me to replace it.  They refused to provide any other assistance in resolving the issue.  The is brand new and the battery should have been fine.  I packed it up and promptly returned this dangerous product to Amazon.

Installed in inexpensive but decent Chamberlain garage door opener a couple of years ago. Selling the house so did not go all out. When we walk the dogs, we go into the car and grab a car remote - the old number pad we had outside got flaky so took it down. Got tired of needing to go into the car to get the remote and put it back.Saw this on Amazon. $40. Install via cell phone instructions simple. Synced up immediately. shows if door is open or closed (as well as the camera I have in my garage). Set up an alert to show when the door opens that sends a push notification. So, if we leave the house, and forget to close the door, no more driving back to close it. If it opens and we are not there, we get the notification. can add another sensor for the other door using same base unit. Small cost for a big improvement. INcidentally, it is manufactured in Mexico.

I’ve been waiting for a device like the MyQ hub for a while and finally The Father’s Day Special of $38 convinced me to give this one a try.Installation is easy if you follow the instruction on the MyQ app. In my case that’s on iOS and while it’s not the easiest to navigate once to leave the “wizard”, it does work well to eliminate nearly all need for printed instructions.

My Q doesn't work, I tried to pair it  W/my Craftsman opener and it won't operate the opener at all even dough it paired up, the only think that works W/it is the door switch. Now I ask you what kind of a unit it is, well I tell you it isn't what Chamberlain says that it supposed to do. It is bad that I'm stuck W/the unit and loosing out on $79.99 for it. When received the unit I had it for  2 Months , because it was winter & and I couldn't install it because of the extreme cold weather that we had in Dec. of 2018, so now the return window is closed for it to return it for refund W/Amazon I don't blame them that rules are rules and we all have to follow them. Don't blow your money on it like me be wise don't buy it. If the star ratting was less then one I would give a glimpse of a star.
I like this device. It does what it is supposed to do but doesn't particularly play well with others.Pros:

Pros:- Super simple installation.  Only two pieces, the hub itself and a tilt sensor.  The Tilt sensor sticks on the inside of a garage door via velcro strips and is powered by a small battery.  It has a push button for synchronization.  The hub, is attached to the ceiling near the garage unit.

Bought because of price point, functionality and manufacturer.  Price point; under $50.  Functionality; if your garage door opener motor  has a “learn” button on the back (regardless of color (it should work, check out my picture for location and what it looks like; mine is purple). As for MFG; chamberlain is well respected in garage doors.  If you have WI-FI arhat reaches into your garage (use you cell phone to check; it should work), if you have a spare opening on the power plug that your garage door motor is plugged into, it should work.  So make sure you have a Lear button on your opener, Wi-Fi reaches the garage, you have power within 6 feet of the garage motor. A critical requirement is to mount the MYIQ hub  (the bigger box that is (in my picture) mounted to the ceiling) within 6 feet of the motor.  This is necessary for it to reliable send commands to your garage door motor to open or close a door! If you are going to install this for two door garage (as in my picture) you will need to buy a second sensor and ensure that you find a sweet spot between the two motors that is no more than 6 feet from either motor; else buy two MYIQ hubs while they are on sale;  it’s only a $10 difference from buying two door sensors.  If his confuses you; send a Q&Q and I will attempt to clarify!

Want to push a button on your phone and have the garage door open? It does this flawlessly.  Want to integrate with Alexa or have the doors open and close as you arrive or leave... well... at least for me, that is far from flawless. The MyQ Alexa app doesn't exist anymore, you have to use the SimpleCommands app to bridge MyQ to Alexa and it isn't 100% flawless. The Alexa integration allows me to tell her to open and close the garage doors and it does give me Amazon Key functionality, which is nice, but the location-based control is very hit or miss. For me, it works sometimes, but I can't depend on it at all. I don't dare just drive away and assume the door will close. I always have to check the MyQ app and if it closes, cool, if not, I have to press the button... which is kind of cool, it is like having an infinite range garage door opener, but still, the point it automation, not infinite range.I'm glad I got it, it controls both my double door opener (1994 model) and my single door controller (2016 model) equally well (had to purchase a 2nd sensor). The door mounted sensor gives me perfect confidence that I know from remote if the door is opened or closed.
Seems to work.  For the price, it's a good value to add wifi to the garage opener without the complexity of upgrading your opener.During install, ran into the following:

The first rule of instructions are always "Read all the instructions BEFORE beginning".  This is impossible because the instructions are on the phone app, and require you to go through each step and make decisions and act on them before you even SEE the next step!  When only one garage door would work, and I tried to re-install the second it told my I had used up my allotment and needed to buy another hub! I finally had to call Tech Support and they put me through a whole lot of useless steps, like repositioning the sensors, moving the hub closer, etc.  I suggested a full factory reset so I could start over, and was told "no, that won't work"  I was told to remove the LED bulbs in the openers, etc, etc.Then the connection was lost.  I don't know if they hung up on me or it was accidental, but I was never called back.  Meanwhile, I FINALLY figured out how to do a factory reset, re-initialized the sensors (Pull the battery completely and replace it.)  I got everything working and remounted the hub, and the 2nd garage wouldn't work.  So I had to reposition the hub hallway between the openers and figure how to power it.  NOW it works, but it cancelled all the programming on the remotes so I had to re-program all of them.  Setting up someone who works for us as a guest was pretty easy.

I installed this on my Chamberlain Liftmaster Professional (circa 2010) garage door opener. I read with some trepidation about the installation problems that others had. My installation went smoothly and as simply as it could given that it has to "pair" the sensor, hub, opener and wifi.The iPhone app is well-crafted and works fine. I'm glad to see it supports Face ID to log in.

I'm using an older Chamberlain ("Access Master" branded/ Home Depot exclusive) opener.As others have said, follow the instructions.  The app itself guides you through the install with in-line videos and step by step instructions.  I paired the head unit with my wi-fi network and the door sensor in the house, then unplugged and installed everything in the garage.  My garage is abt 60 feet from my wifi router in the house, it connected instantly with no problem.  You have to use 2.4 ghz wifi, not 5.0.  2.4 has longer range.  You have to pair the head unit with 3 things, in this order:

I have two garage doors. So, I bought the smart hub and an extra sensor from Amazon. I considered getting Nexx Garage at first since, it had better reviews on Amazon. But I went with Chamberlain for ease of installation and setup. According to the Chamberlain both of my openers (LiftMaster 8500 & Wayne Dalton iDrive) seemed compatible or that's what I thought. The installation was easy however, setup was not.It turned out that LiftMaster 8500 didn't have a program/learn button that's either purple, red, yellow etc. So, I couldn't get past the step on the app where you are supposed to enter the color of the program button. I then called Chamberlain support. To my surprise, the tech support rep said LiftMaster 8500 is not going to work. I would need an additional internet gateway. This was very disappointing. I didn't want to buy another component plus this information should have been stated in the compatibility list. It clearly was not. So, I decided to return everything the next day. But before returning it, I tried few other things (I'm an engineer). One of things I tried worked and I was able to program the LiftMaster with Chamberlain after couple of hours.

Ordered the Smart Hub right before Christmas.. wanted to be sure all packages made it safe as the porch thieves were tracking the delivery vans in herds. Received the Smart Hub and my husband - NOT a techy at all- had the system installed, up and running within 30 minutes. Our garage door opener is approximately 10 years old so we had concerns... but there were no problems! It connected right away and we were able to sit in the living room and open and close the door just for kicks! We only connected it to one door, given we ordered it specifically for Amazon deliveries. Sitting at work I am notified when husband opens and closes the door! Haha.Now, when we order, there is an added option for "garage delivery" and we simply choose that. It was SO nice to be away for the week after Christmas and to get notified there was a package coming, be notified the door was opening, and one minute later notified the door was closing; and when we arrived home our Amazon package was sitting safely inside our garage. PERFECT SOLUTION!

I tried to install the My Q but it did not work with my new garage door opener. This opener acts as a remote opener just like the opener you keep in your vehicle, instead of wiring directly in to the unit like the switch mounted to the wall of your garage. Because of the security measures employed by newer openers (rolling codes, encryption, etc.) the MyQ is not compatible with many newer model garage door openers. Frankly, I think it's a bad design and leaves the opener incompatible with many units from all manufacturers, and that will only get worse as garage door manufacturers add more security features. If you have a newer opener, try the Gogogate 2. It works flawlessly with my opener manufactured in 2018.

The product looked great and for the money was very reasonable.  Once I attempted to install using the app on my phone, ran into issues  trying to connect to the hub.  Decided to switch to using my pad, and then then I was able to establish initial communications to the hub so that I could tell it what wifi network to connect to and enter the password.  After that the installation went smooth by following the step by step install instructions on the app.  So everything worked after the initial install.  The 2 garage doors I installed opened and closed from my phone app.  The next day I tried to open the doors, no response.  The doors were unresponsive.  When to the hub and the green light was solid (Which I think means it is connected to the wifi network).  The app showed no issues with communications to the hub, nor did it report any other problems.  It just didn't work.  Manually I opened the garage door and I did not receive any change of status for the garage door being open.  I decided to cycle power to the hub, surprisingly no message of the hub being disconnected or anything was wrong.  Not too impressed with this being an home automation product.  Another negative is I could not find a skill that would connect to the MyQ and allow control of the garage through Alexa.  You can connect using the Amazon Key for deliveries, but I didn't want to use that.  Overall I would not recommend this product.

There is nothing not to like.Installation is simple as long as you have a good WiFi signal.  The app (I have an iPhone) is clean and the response time, considering it has to go to the Chamberlain servers via the internet, before going back to my home server to the WiFi, is pretty good.  Select the remote command - only the appropriate one OPEN or CLOSE, is available - and the door begins to move within 3 or 4 seconds.

Had it installed and working in less than 25 min. And I am a 66 year old woman. Hardest part was getting the ladder off the wall and moving it to where I needed it. Seems to be working just fine. The alarm sound however is SO ANNOYING. I really see no reason for it. All standard garage door openers don't have alarms. That is why they have the sensors so in the event someone stupidly walks under the door when it is closing it will stop and reverse. That function still works with the MyQ. So absolutely NO reason for the annoying alarm. I also wish it would integrate with Alexa. Overall an excellent purchase for the money.

First of all, credit where credit is due. I've had this installed for a week and it's working very well. The installation was very smooth, probably the smoothest of any home automation product I've ever used. I didn't have to think at all during setup. Physical installation might have been challenging if I had mounted the hub on the ceiling as recommended (would have required a 12-foot ladder) but I just rested it on top of the garage fridge and it works fine.Having said all that, anyone purchasing this thing should know in advance that even though they tout integration with Amazon Key (a useless feature for me), there is absolutely zero integration with Alexa. Chamberlain decided at some point to nickle and dime their customers by charging $1 / month for the great privilege of controlling their stupid little device with standard home automation techniques. For example, you can control it with Google Home, but only if you shell out $1 / month. And you can't use Alexa AT ALL. So I can't pull into my driveway and tell Echo Auto to open the garage door, which would be a natural and smooth implementation. Instead, I have to open my phone, open the app, wait for authentication, and click the button in the app before the door will open.

It is easy to install with wireless connection between both the door unit and the controller mounted to the ceiling.  However, Chamberlain and their garage door app MyQ was removed from Alexa skills due to their requirement to pay a yearly fee for the privelege of having their Oh So Fantastic garage door opener.  I returned mine and decided to settle on Nexx Garage.  It takes a little more work to run the wiring and mount the sensor but easily doable for most DIY folks.  Nexx Garage app has been working flawlessly and after downloading IFTT I can simply say "Alexa close the garage door" and the door closes within a few seconds.

To make the door smart, you need to install a battery-powered puck on your door. The battery lasts about a month.The puck must be paired to the hub. Occasionally, the puck would become unpaired from the hub after battery replacement, and you have to go through the setup again.

Would give 5 stars as it is a great product and does what I bought it for. However to utilize with Alexa you must pay for the service, very minimal cost but the fact that I can’t have my echo device open my garage door and must get my phone, open the app, then click on the “open” garage door is quite a bit more time consuming.

Received the MYQ-G0301.  There is no step by instruction in the box. You download the app to your smartphone Myq and it walks you through the setup step by step.  The instruction is very clear.  It did take several tries to connect to my wifi network.  Once it did connect it ran okay in the continued setup until sync to the door opener motor, again it took several tries of pushing the learn button before it syncs with the motor.  Other than two items the setup was very easy.There is a warning sound when the door is starting to close and continues until after the door is shut.  Guess this is good as you are not there to actually see that no one is standing in the way of the closing

Love this product which allows my older garage door opener to be smart.  I can open/close the garage with the use of my iPhone and it tells me the status of the door anytime and how long it had been at that state.  You have the option to have it automatically close at a certain time of the day to. It also integrates w/ Amazon Key App which gives you the option to have them deliver your package inside the garage, safe from thieves. Amazon will actually g I've you $30 for the 1st delivery using the Key App, making this purchase almost FREE.  This also integrates with the Brinks Home Security System for Free but I opted out of that to start out with because I will need MyQ to delete the serial # from their system and remove the app from my iPhone before Brinks can add it to their system.  I want to make sure Amazon's Key App will still work with the Brinks app before implementing it.Installation was pretty easy except for one step that the myq app bypassed  (the pairing) so I had to call support &we just deleted it & restarted.  Support was outstanding.

I tried a different remote opener system and returned it because it didn't work with my MyQ compatible door opener. I decided to try to see if I could get control of both my old school and smart garage door openers. This thing works great!PROs:

Great product, by a quality company.  I have wanted to add this to my garage for 2 years, didn't think I would be able to since I didn't own one of the chamberlain products.  When I saw this I thought it was capable of being added to any opener.  I found out that I couldn't add to my Horman opener.  I recently came across some used lift master add on remote units for upgrading older openers to the new remotes.  I added the liftmaster units to my openers and programed them to the MyQ hub and installed and programed in the door position sensor and she works like a charm.My only complaint so far is it doesn't respond to my phone sometimes when I am backing out.  Could be my wifi signal not sure.  But it is nice when coming home I can open it out in the street and by the time I get to the garage the door is open.

This product is absolutely garbage. Stay away!We have a smart home. Lights, thermostats, cameras, the works. I build computers for fun. This product does not work. Worse, it actively breaks the baseline functionality of the normal remote control openers.

This solved a BIG problem for us: Did we or didn't we close the garage door when we drove away? Facing the street on the driveway (backing in) and using the car's remote, we always THOUGHT we knew but were sometimes NOT SURE and had to drive back home! Sometimes open, sometimes closed. Now we don't have to worry! So I've substituted constantly checking the app for worrying...!Actually, this went in very very simply - and will for you IF you already have the following: an open power plug on the ceiling next to or very near to you CURRENT COMPATIBLE GARAGE DOOR OPENER MOTOR!  A power drill to drill a couple of holes in your garage ceiling. Safety glasses! A 5/32 drill bit (or close...I used a 9/64, good enough). A ladder. A WiFi network that's 4 of 5 bars strong near the door motor.

I purchased this because indoor delivery via my front door would set off my Ring alarm. I was hoping Amazon would integrate indoor delivery with Ring since they own the company. Even though I didn't mind a delivery person having access to my front door only when a delivery is made, I still prefer having it placed in the garage. I also like being able to remotely open or close my garage.The installation and setup were easy and the instructions were more than sufficient. I chose to install the hub on a beam in my garage because I had an injured left arm and couldn't reach up that high. I placed the door sensor to line up with the hub and they are within a couple feet of each other when the garage door is open.

I don't write a lot of reviews but the main reason I wrote this review is because so many of the other reviews say nothing but negative things (ad nauseum) about the condition of the box or the condition of the product and about how it was so hard to install or that it took so much longer than it should have, or that it didn't work with their existing Wi-Fi or that it didn't do this or that, or they were complaining about the beeper and on and on and on.  I don't care for the beeper either but I don't ever hear it because I'm not there when I'm using the app to close the garage door!  Isn't that the point-- to be able to open and close the garage door remotely?  Let me tell you I had the unit up and running in no time.  True there were no printed instructions but the PHONE app which you should install before you do anything walks you right through it, simple step by step.  I hit no snags during the installation and even the hollow wall anchors went in correctly and I'm usually the type that has lots of trouble with those things!And on top of this I bought a used (listed as very good condition) product at a fraction of the price of the new one... So I don't know where those reviews come from that say that used products do not work for them.  Thanks for reading.

If you are thinking about purchasing this, please read this!First, I was looking at this for my somewhat older opener model.  However, after a few hours of research and testing I found out my opener already had this built in!  It does not have WiFi enabled but it has the MyQ signal logo on the side.  Upon learning this, all I needed was the Smarthub to plug into my router to make it compatible with HomeKit.  If you have a similar set up or desire, all you need is the module that plugs into your router for Alex, Google assistant, etc.  However, if you do not have this tech then this is your solution.

Very easy to install and set up.  Wish they offered a 2 garage pack as an option as well.  I had to buy a 2nd MyQ box for my 2nd garage door, but overall I am very happy with the product.This product is great for use, especially with Vivint.  They just recently integrated it with their system and it has been so easy to use and monitor with having kids who leave garage doors open.

We primarily got this to know whether we left our garage door open when leaving the house and when we go on long trips we get OCD on whether we left it open and have to turn around to double check. This product does absolutely great with showing up whether the door is open or closed as well as giving notifications when the door is open or closed. The problem we have had so far is once we are off out wifi network on our phones the doors does not respond to the open / close command. It has worked maybe twice since we had it. The unit and senor are both locating within 1 1/2 feet one one another when the door is open and probably 5'-6' when it's closed. wifi shows a very strong signal. I will walk our dog in the morning and when walking back I will press the "open" function from the app on my phone to test it. We are only about .1 mile away when I do. It just goes in circles as though it's trying to connect to the unit and open the door. It times out about every time and I try again to no avail (except a couple times). Yesterday it even came back with a "timed out" message saying there were too many failed attempts to connect and the only way to reset it was to be at the hours and control the door from the wall unit in our garage or the remote control on our car or the handheld unit. But the main purpose we got it was to tell if/when our door is open/closed so that's why the 3 star rating. The ability to actually open / closed through the App when off our home wifi is another story.

I should have listened to the bad reviews on this product.  I haven't been able to use any of the devices I purchased on my garage since I haven't been able to get past the app installation, which is atrocious.  I had to use FIVE different email accounts to try to set up an account, and even then, I still haven't been able to set up an account.  I enter all my information but never received a confirmation email to allow me to finish setting up my account on any of the emails I used.  I checked every single folder on each of the emails but didn't get a single email from them.  I contacted support and was on with them for over an hour and they weren't able to solve my issue.  Instead, they told me to contact google since they didn't have a server down and their emails must be getting blocked.  WHAT?!  I used a google email, yahoo email, outlook email, iCloud email and NONE of them worked so how can it be that every single one of those providers on different apps and websites isn't allowing your emails to come through?  Yes, this is cheaper than most other options but the app, setup, customer service, and just about everything for this product is a joke.

So many mixed reviews. Are people not following directions? Likely. Do people have a weak signal in their garage? Good possibility. Should some people not be allowed around technology? Definitely! I was hesitant after the mixed reviews. But there's something to be said for over ten thousand positive reviews and number one bestseller. I also like the idea of a wired button and magnetic contact switch that others have over the "this is just another remote" approach the MyQ uses. However, there's also something to be said for a simpler install, portability, fewer wires, and cleaner looking.Just as others have said, follow the instructions. That's the best advice I can give you. If reading comprehension is not your strength, why are you reading reviews? Hire a handyman. The whole setup, and installation, was very quick and easy. If you can hang a picture, you can do this! I did not attempt to integrate with Amazon Alexa, Google, or ITTT. My new car does not have a Home Link mirror, so no remote. I didn't want an ugly clicker on my visor, and just something to leave behind in a rental car/truck. I've always got my phone, and if I didn't I couldn't close the garage until I ran in and grabbed it! Not to mention how many times did I already arm the alarm, but not yet check the garage door? A lot! how many times was the door left open all night? Even once is too many. How many times did I drive away and wonder, did I leave the door open? I see no mention of monthly fees for my install, and I did set up alarms in case the door was left open or did not close properly. I love the idea of turning my garage into my own Amazon Locker! How many times have I worried about packages on the porch? The whole install consists of two pieces of velcro and two drywall anchors with screws. The setup of the whole system was installing an App and pressing two buttons. If that frightens you, hire a handyman, or buy your neighbor a beer. As for that super loud, extremely annoying door close alarm that bothers the neighbors, perhaps they've toned it down. It beeps and a little LED light flashes. That's all there is to it. A power failure messes it up? I had it plugged into the wall for the setup, and disconnected it and moved everything for the final install. Nothing was lost. An extended power outage may be a different story, but how often does that happen? The device loses connectivity? Not that I have seen so far. Perhaps it's time to invest in a better router or access point? Chamberlain's support was/was not helpful? Chamberlain's support was not necessary. The device takes too long to respond. If nearly instantly is too long. My wife likes a clean garage. That means almost nothing is stored in the garage. Certainly nothing of value. But that also means this device received approval for it's clean, simplistic, nice looking install. Her words were, "Very nice." I'm happy. The wife is happy. What more could you want? I hope I've addressed all your concerns. Reading comprehension, hire a handyman or buy your neighbor a beer. That's really all there is to it.

I spent days trying to setup this device. I read what I could find here and online (thanks to user Steve for all his tips). I also contacted Chamberlain support. The sticking point was that I could never get beyond the WiFi setup, using my iPhone. The device would seem to connect to WiFi, but the setup would not continue. I tried an iPad -- no-go. I tried an old WiFi access point, configured just for this device. Still no joy. Finally, I dug out an old Android phone. Finally! Using the Android app, I was able to go through the setup of the WiFi connection, effortlessly.So, lesson learned -- use or borrow an Android phone to setup this device. The iOS app will not work well for initial setup, if at all. The iOS app works great once the system is setup and you have an account established. And, using a static IP address (configured on my router), I have not had the device go offline from my WiFi since initial setup.

I rediscovered this product while browsing the Amazon Black Friday deals.  When I originally found this product, I decided not to buy it mainly because in order to use it with my voice assistants (Alexa or Google) I had to pay a reoccurring subscription.  But MyQ now allows me to do this for free, so due to them fixing the deal killer and because it was highly discounted, I thought I would give it a try.Features I like:

So when I got this I had high hopes. For me, it was not difficult to set up but I did read a bit at the problems others were having before doing it, but honestly, setup was easy. The problem for me that showed up very quickly was the door sensor. Very early on, it did not seem to know if the door was open or closed. I called Chamberlain, and to their credit, and they sent out a new sensor, which within a 2 weeks did the some thing. To be fair, I did not contact them again as I figured this was what causes this item to have average reviews This is on me but I suspect it is a problem with the product line. Here is the problem-if you use this as a remote access for your door and the sensor malfunctions, you could end up with your garage door being open when you are not there. Honestly, I do not even use it anymore. Half the time it says the door is open when it isn't and vice versa. Anyway, there are really no features much that this offers in my opinion as compared to the chance you take of having your garage door being wide open with nothing you can do about it. I have a lot of smart devices around my home-smart switches, smart light bulbs, smart plugs, Alexa, Arlo Cameras, Ring Cameras, etc. They all work together really well. This is in the other category-I would not buy it again.

One, do yourself a favor and get the bundle with the little Wi-Fi extender, so you can be rest assured that you have adequate coverage in your garage.  Seriously, don't cheap out; it's only like ten dollars more. Secondly, if you've had installation problems on this, you should just go back to owning a flip phone, black and white TV, Sony Walkman (the cassette type), 8-track player, or Betamax, as clearly high tech is not for you.  Since, I live in Wisconsin, and it was 9 degrees, I set up the Wi-Fi extender in the house, before journeying to my detached garage.  Once you have the wifi extender setup, you can move it wherever you want.  I went out to the garage and plugged the little extender in, waited for both blue lights to be solid, then moved onto the myQ device. Setup could not be easier, and I didn't even do things in the order that they ask you to in the instructions.  Begin with the DOOR CLOSED. I did this anyway since it was freezing cold, but apparently that's what's expected anyway. I found an unoccupied outlet above waist level, mounted the hub bracket with my 1/4 inch hex driver, slid the hub on the bracket, then plugged it in. The app walks you through the process at like a third grade understanding level.  A couple of flashes, and button presses, and the door sensor and hub were paired. Reached up and hit the "learn" button, and the app and hub synced that in like another 45 seconds. It opened up the door.  I stepped out of the garage and hit the little garage looking icon on my screen, and 10-15 seconds later, light was flashing, alert was sounding, and door closed. It's literally not even a one beer job; guys you know what I'm talking about...  Had my wife been home at the time, I probably would have spent more time checking the Bleacher Report and/or ESPN app, but she wasn't, so I digress.  So, point being, unless you are a baby-boomer, it's easy peasy lemon squeezy (sorry dad; the thing that looks like a paper clip in your email is an attachment, and the thing that looks like a paper airplane, on your snooty iPhone, that you don't know how to use, is the messaging send icon).

This works great on my Liftmaster opener. Not surprising since Chamberlain makes Liftmaster. I followed the step by step instructions in the app, and I was done in about 20 minutes.I added a second door sensor since I have two garage doors, and the second one only took about 5 minutes to install and configure. The second door is powered by a Genie opener, and the MyQ was able to program it first try.
So this was very simple and fast to install with my opener....took maybe 10 minutes.In that time, it was working perfectly with MyQ app.
I have never been so aggravated by the setup of a simple electronic device in my life.There are two things they don't tell you in the manual that you need to know to make this work.

We just got a new Chamberlain WiFi capable garage door opener for our barn, after installing it convinced me to finally make our other dumb opener "smart".Our dumb opener is a newer Chamberlain without WiFi, so I've been looking into this MyQ hub, anyway, waiting for a good deal. It just so happens, while boredom browsing, I found a MyQ hub in the Amazon Warehouse with only damaged packaging for VERY little money. (I don't think I can reveal what I paid exactly, so I'll just say less than a large fancy coffee!) Couldn't pass that up, and the package "damage" looked only like it had been opened previously and taped back closed.

I wasn't sure why I needed this thing. It opens my garage door on my phone and what else? Oh, it allows Amazon to deliver packages indoors? Ok. Why not?That was pretty much my thought process. I got it for $23 on Treasure Truck, it only runs $29 at full price though. The packaging comes with a door sensor, a small installation kit and the main MyQ Door Hub. Instructions are all online via the App, but are easy enough to follow. Specifically, they will show you a short video and then step you through the process with illustrations.

I got this working on a Genie 2028 Professional Series installed by my builder in a newly built august 2019 home. It was a very discouraging process, and it took me 1-2 hours to get it synced properly.The problem for me was 2 things.

Think this is quite a bargain under $30. Skipped the optional IFTTT and Google Home integration with the ridiculous monthly fee. Don't need that sort of security hole anyway.The app walked me through installation and setup. I let the phone die after the first part was done, pairing the Bluetooth sensor to the base and connecting the base to the network (WiFi only, despite some comments here to the contrary). Was pleasantly surprised to find that it showed the status and offered an intuitive way to finish the installation (learning the opener's RF code). At first I had trouble with that step, until I realized that it was waiting to hear feedback from the sensor, which I hadn't yet mounted. Should have followed the instructions a little more carefully.

The installation is a bit of a chore, but it actually works. My first attempt at connecting my old Raynor Pilot garage door opener online was the Nexx Garage. Unfortunately the magnet sensor was too finicky for my 1990's-era 8'-ft sectional garage door, and it would not align properly half the time. This MyQ uses a clever tilt sensor which doesn't care how much slop there is in the door tracks.The MyQ tilt sensor has a wireless connection to the hub, while the Nexx needed a wired magnet sensor at the top of my door. The tilt sensor uses a CR2450 coin cell for power. Both of mine lasted about 6 months before the hub sent me notifications via the MyQ app that the battery was low and needed to be replaced soon. One of them kept working for almost 2 weeks before I installed a new battery.

I was really excited about this device. A few days after installation, we went out of town. The person taking care of the house called in a panic that the garage door was open.  I checked the app and sure enough, the garage door had opened itself. After this happened a couple of times, I found how to set up notifications so I would know when this happened. It wasn’t too bad because I was able to close it remotely. The last couple of times it happened, I was notified but then the unit would not close (too many attempts, then disconnected from WiFi) and the app told me to close the door locally. I wasn’t home which is why I need this product. Last night, it happened again and I had to leave my post at work to close the garage door where my family was sleeping (I work nights and no one heard their phones). This product is dangerous and has put my family and home at risk by opening spontaneously about once a week. The device losing connection with the WiFi after the alert and just telling me to close the door locally was of no value. I ran home during my shift to close the door and unplug it. Do not buy this!

I picked these up for 29 dollars on sale.  I have had in the past a number of occasions in which my garage door was left open.  I believe that during the winter, snow and ice build up and get in the way of the garage door closing causing the garage door to pop back up.  I have an Xfinity home security system which alerts me to when the garage door stays open for more than 5 minutes.  But it is a pain to have to drive back to close the garage door.I have been wanting a product like this for a while and when I found it on sale, i definitely had to give it a try.  I was not disappointed.  The installation took me about 20 minutes and the MyQ app I had installed on my Iphone, provided me all the guidance I needed.  Do ensure your garage door opener is compatible with this system.

The price for myQ Smart Garage Door Opener Chamberlain MYQ-G0301 - Wireless & Wi-Fi enabled Garage Hub has finally come down to a reasonable price making them worthwhile solutions by adding phone App convenience.PROS:

Troubleshooting with Chamberlain was a mess but the word is this: WPA3 is not supported on this MyQ product with the firmware it has on it when it ships.In speaking with support for several hours on two separate occasions we finally identified that if you use Eero Pro and have enabled WPA 3 it will not work.

I have been looking for a smart garage door solution, but hesitated on this one because some of the reviews say that there will be a paid subscription to make it work. When the price came down below $30, I decided to give it a try, and I am happy with it!The installation was easy. I downloaded the myQ app on my phone, and followed the step-by-step instructions from the app. Basically you attach a door sensor with velcro stickers, and the wireless hub to the wall (or ceiling) with screws. The whole process took 10 - 15 mins. Now I can check the status of the my garage door on my phone. I can open and close the door remotely with my phone.
Easy to install.Text too long to authenticate user. It’s like every time you want to use the app to bring down the garage door you have to wait 6 seconds to seven seconds for it to login.

I already had a Z-Wave garage door controller, but it was not controllable by Alexa and didn't support Amazon Key. The MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener does at least support* Amazon Key. Unfortunately Amazon Key is not available in my area, so minor flop. If this is important to you, check Amazon's supported areas before you purchase.My existing controller closed a physical switch to send the "Open/Close" command to the opener. Imagine my intense concern when the only wired connection to this device is for power. I had checked my opener for compatibility before I purchased the controller, so I thought I must have made some kind of mistake. After packing it back into the box, I did some research on the installation of MyQ and discovered it uses the same RF signal as a typical transmitter.

Bought two of these for my two garage doors. Used the same hub for both. When I initially installed these they both worked fine, while in the garage. The one closest to the hub would only work occasionally, like after a manual open.In my troubleshooting, I recognized the sensor farther from the hub worked 100% of the time. I understand LED/florescent lights might cause a problem, but that wasn't the case in my shop - tried it with them on and off with no difference in operation or notification to my phone. I considered the battery might be weak in the closest one, but they sensors were likely the same age. I noticed I had the hub oriented with the power connection towards the closest sensor. So I turned the hub facing the sensor and, so far, that seems to have resolved my issue.
This is seriously got to be one of the easiest things I have ever installed in my life!The only thing harder than this is walking a straight line.

I purchased this unit as a "returned item" from Amazon.  Saved a few bucks.After two days, I was not successful completing the setup via iPhone 11 Pro Max.  My iPhone would not connect to the smart opener.  I tinkered my network to ensure proper communication with the opener, still no success.  I was about to pack it and return it.  However, I tried another method.

MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener Chamberlain MYQ-G0301  work for me everything is great. Make sure its 2.4ghz wifi you don't need 5.4ghz to tell it open and close didn't try but I don't think it will work. straight to the point of my review is the main reason I got this is notification my garage door is open. Our garage door remote doesn't have a cover for the open and close button so it can accidentally press open by dropping it. Anything like stuff in the bag could press it if bag was move around. That what happen luckily our neighbor was outside notice Garage door was open and our dogs ran out around the into the street. Garage door was open for few minute people could have taken our garage stuff my tools our random garage stuff some valuable stuff. My face id Iphone sometime doesn't like me that would help you login quicker. You can set up when you get closer to the garage door when your driving your car. I personal have not try that yet I can see some situation problems with that me walking around the house doing gardening. Everything working for me Have try other features so that the my short review. This last part I don't think this apply to most haha I think my Garage Door Opener has dead light bulb need to be switch out. I think most garage door have a light buib. At night it can get pretty dark and I can not see a thing. I sometime I come home pretty late moving grocery from the outside and my light switch near the inside house door. I have walk in the dark garage that sometime can get messy from doing work. Just to get to my light switch which is not safe. Yes I know I have my phone flash light so I wish there was some way I can connect MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener Chamberlain MYQ-G0301 to my garage light. I think there is a way i look it up latter. I know I can open it up do modification my garage door opener with smart switch or get separate smart switch for my light making it into one operation.  I do have a bit dent on garage door this happen before we got the house. The garage seem like drunk person tap their car on garage door so now it sometime doesn't close properly. playing with setting help fix it. Sometime it would reopen. I have to press it twice without changing a thing to close it. Maybe getting setting just right would fix it but I know for my family we shouldn't wireless open garage door without someone being home and have to watch the garage door close before leaving. it might hit ground and reopen. But that just be my damage garage door and not MyQ Garage devices. it would show you an error on MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener and you can't do anything to tell it try close again. I even try login  again hoping give me another chance to close garage door nope same message. well sometime think it did. maybe there was an update not sure. The error it tell to use physical button that it was install with garage door. If I wasn't home there no way for me to do that if I did wireless open it for Delivery which I don't just an example to explain the problem. I will update if I discover anything new. Overall good working product.

I’d get this again in a heartbeat. But know that it won’t work with Siri or HomeKit unless you want to pay an additional $60+ For the Cambridge homebridge hardware. It really isn’t an issue though.
