Just open the app and you can view or open/close your door with ease. Setup was great. I have a detached garage and ended up needing an extender to boost my signal. These are not too expensive (around $30), but I had one laying around anyway so it wasn’t an issue. If you have a more powerful router, you might now even need it. If you have an attached garage, you most likely wouldn’t need it anyway.  The set up walks you through it on your phone and doesn’t miss a beat. Very easy. Mounts super quickly too when you’re at that step. Again, I would get this again as my options were to either buy a new door opener at $400 or to get this $37 kit that would do the exact same thing. Make sure your garage door is supported. My craftsman door, which is at least 15 years old, but most likely much older, works perfect.
The only reason this gets 2 stars instead of 1 is because I'm keeping it despite a litany of frustrations and disappointments.Installation was fairly easy.

I compare this technology to my kitchen microwave.... now that I have it, how did we ever  live without it?Installation.... much easier than others have reported. I just sloooooowed down and took every step slowly.

Best Prime Day deal ever! I love that we can check at any time if the garage door is open. You can also set alerts which is very helpful. This is such a great alternative to buying the latest and greatest garage door opener and thus saved us over $100. My only gripe is that once in a while I’ve tried to close the garage door using the app and it didn’t work. We finally found out if this happens it means you need to reset your router. We’ve only had to reset our router once so far and we’ve had this product for several months.Also, great things about this product is you can provide temporary access to open the garage to guests or delivery persons. I like that I can close the garage when my kids forget to close it or i can open it for them if the outside keypad isn’t working properly. Super helpful. Love it!

I'm probably in the minority here since both of my openers were already MyQ enabled (with the MyQ symbol on the opener case). While the MYQ-G0301-E was designed to work with compatible (post 1993) openers of any make, it will actually work with MyQ enabled ones as well. The only caveat is that there is no documentation anywhere that says this, and even the installation instructions do not take this into account. I took the plunge & bought the Smart Garage Hub after chatting with Customer Support who reassured me that my 2 Chamberlain models already had MyQ logic inside & did not require the external sensor to report open/close status correctly.Setting up the main hub was as per instructions, but because my openers were MyQ enabled, I skipped the section for the sensor installation. Instead, I needed to associate the openers to the hub, and to do that I had to pick the "Commercial Opener" in the device selection. The button labeling didn't exactly match my opener, but nevertheless it worked, and now I have 1 spare sensor left over! Installation time, even with a bit of trial & error, was about a 1/2 hour.

The installation of the myQ is extremely simple - you connect it to your Wifi network, pair the myQ to the door sensor attach the sensor to the garage door (with double-sided tape), pair the myQ with your garage door opener, and voila! I have seen other systems that require the sensor to be positioned in a specific place -- not the case here. There are step-by-step instructions in the App, as well as videos, making the installation process a breeze.In term of usage, the App is ok - you can open/close your garage door, as well as set schedules (open door from x to y) and notifications (when door is still open after e.g., 10pm). Other reviewers said that integration with IFTTT is not free but it was free for me, so Chamberlain might have changed their policy recently (which would make sense). There is no integration with Alexa but through IFTTT you can ask myQ to perform operations. The way I did it was to create an IFTTT command that closes the garage door based on an Alexa command (IF Alexa_command THEN close_the_door). By default, you need to insert the word "Trigger" in your Alexa command - for example "Alexa, Trigger Close the Garage Door", but you can create a routine in Alexa to send that command when you simply say "Alexa, Close the Garage Door". Please note that myQ allows commands to close the garage door but not to open it (for security reasons). With the IFTTT integration, you can also close the garage door based on your location. I also used IFTTT to switch on some lights when the garage door is opened.

Let me say that I like and dislike this device for all of the same reasons. After watching a few Youtube videos, and reading the instructions, my first attempt at installation was successfully easy! I enjoy getting home to see potential snatch bandits could not get to my delivered goods because this device allows Amazon deliveries, to be placed inside my garage. However it is equally un-nerving to be home and see a strange truck pull into your drive way, and before you can investigate, the truck is pulling out and the driver just looks at you without speaking. Further investigation leads me to find a new package resting on the trunk lid of my car parked inside my garage. I never heard the garage door open, nor did the delivery person try ringing the bell first. So this device has its pluses and minuses. I can now allow friends or family access to the house or borrow things from me by placing them in the garage. I can operate the garage door remotely via the phone app, and the app tells me the current garage door status and approximately how long it has been since the last status change. Example: Door is Closed, for 11 hours. Now the minuses: The app doesn't tell me who, or how the door was opened or closed. Delivery persons now have access to place items into or take items out of my garage, car etc. The app doesn't say the door was opened at 10:20 am for 2 minutes then closed. With access to the garage, the door to the house from the garage is sometimes unlocked, but still protected by house alarm. Now I need to purchase and place camera's within the garage to monitor what gets placed into or removed from the garage. So although this device helps to solve some security concerns, it also introduces a few additional security concerns. I do not use Alexa so I don't honestly now how this device integrates with Alexa. Equally I am not sure if Alexa will alert me when the garage door is opened/closed or by whom. Now the App itself.. if you open the app to view the current status of your garage door. You may inadvertently open/close the garage door by just touching your phone screen, when you just wanted to check the status. There is no button within the app or clear-cut way to close the app without changing the door status. You have to either hit your back button twice, or tap your close all button to correctly close the app. However the phone App itself responds fast to open/close screen taps.  Again, My likes of this device currently out weighs my dislikes of having the device. The device does what it was intended to do, it will beep and a light will blink to let people/pets near the garage door know that the door is about to close. A great product when used properly and as intended. The included instructions where well written and easy to follow.

[Edited 5/17/2020]A replacement unit (under warranty, see below) has arrived. It installed quickly and started working right away, confirming the Chamberlain technician's suspicion that the original unit went out of order. We are hoping that the short life span of our original unit is an anomaly which will not befall upon this replacement.

I had earlier purchased a higher rated smartphone remote control for the opener.  And quickly returned it. I was expecting something would use the learn button on the opener.  The one I returned required wires into the opener and despite a long list compatible openers, my 10 year old Liftmaster wasn’t one of them.The MyQ opener however is very easy to installed.  You start by downloading the app and the app walks you through everything.
I'm using the device for 4 months and now I'm ready to return this piece of plastic.The main issue you will need to set up a connection to the garage door opener monthly to make it work properly.

Got this one at Thanksgiving and I've had it up and running since.  Installation was a PITA.  First time through with the app, the unit would not pair with my garage door opener (18 year old Genie).Once it fails to pair, the app really doesn't seem to offer an easy way to try again.  The only solution seems to be to uninstall the app and re-install to start over fresh.  Did that twice before I figured out why it wouldn't pair with the Genie opener.

The set up was easy and it's already told me a couple of times when my garage has been left open more than the specified amount of time, which was nice.  I've also been able to use it to remotely open/close the garage door when needed, also nice.  It claims to have support for Google Assistant, but when I went through the support documents for this, created an account on the Chamberlain site (which they are going to charge for in the future), got everything ready, when I searched for "MyQ" in Google Assistant, I got nothing but empty screen (I also tried other variations, including "Chamberlain", but no luck).I thought I'd let Chamberlain know, so I contacted their support, the suggestion from support is that this wasn't their problem, that I should contact Google and ask them why the MyQ app wasn't showing in Google Assistant, which was possibly the laziest response I've gotten from support before.  I told them that this was possibly due to a change Google made in the 3rd quarter of 2019 and that they may want to discuss with their internal development team to get this straightened away.

It was super easy to set up and I received a $30 rebate since I had a Key delivery before 4/1/20, so it was almost free. I think we should all do our part to thwart package thieves and this  is great solution for people who have a garage. You can give access securely, but inexpensively to your garage, but keep your house off limits to Prime Delivery.The image above is from my Reolink camera. I didn't buy the Amazon Cloud Camera because it is a rip off. Reolink has free cloud storage for 7 days on one camera or you can us an SD card. All security cameras have motion sensors nowadays and cost around $30. The Cloud Key Camera is close to $120, which is outrageous...That's a lot to pay just to have a camera linked to the key app. Instead, I get a Key alert on my phone from this wifi hub on my garage door. I then know the time of the delivery. I then just open my Reolink camera app and can find the footage of  the delivery if I want to view it. Pretty easy. Get this device and get Amazon Key if you want to help get rid of package thieves. The only negative I have seen is that deliveries are slower by a day, because it takes the delivery person longer to open and close your garage than it would to just set the package down. I bet this improves though, as the service expands. Love it!

The MyQ app works great. You can check the open/closed status of your garage door and both open and close the garage door. However, if you want to geek out and try to automate things, you quickly find that you are only allowed to close the door using IFTTT or Google Home.  I corresponded with Chamberlain and was told that this was a safety feature. Chamberlain does not allow voice assistants to open the door. I though it would be neato-torpedo if the door opened automatically when me/wife arrived home but it's not to be. First world problems! I feel like Chamberlain is only telling you a half-truth with respect to "compatible with..."  I tried to enable Amazon Key, but my location is not serviced.

The installation and the app-based instructions worked out really well. Note, that the inbox user manual is minimal. The functionality is also better than anticipated, probably due to my low initial expectation of the product. But there is not much to it, really.What I did not expect was that the base unit communicates wirelessly with the garage opener. I was hoping it would be wired as some of the openers have a limited number of entries, so if you have  several clickers (portable or in-car) this might be limiting.

Bottom line up front-don’t buy this garbageThis item will work great for a while. I have a lot of tools in my garage and my wife has a tendency to leave the garage door open when she comes home, leaving my garage vulnerable to theft.

Wow ... so close to being “great”. VERY loud beeping every time you close the door from the app. And it’s not like a couple warning beeps (like a smoke detector low battery warning) ... nope, it’s about 30 seconds of LOUD beeping every time. What’s the point?? This is no different than someone clicking a remote from a car pulling up the street or from inside the house when there’s no view of the garage door. That’s why there are sensors on a garage door that don’t allow it to close if something is blocking. Beeping is fine as an OPTIONAL safety precaution, but not allowing the consumer to control it is beyond poor design.If this is actually a necessary safety feature, then every garage door remote unit should be required by law to have loud warning beeps before engaging the motor. And since no such law exists (nor ever will), there is no need for this device to implement such a thing.

I got this product specifically because it said it worked with IFTTT. When I went to connect it, it said it couldn’t find the door. Thinking it was a technical issue, I called the MyQ tech support. I told them that it wasn’t finding the door, then I noticed that it said “Note: close actions are not compatible with MyQ” now, I can understand this for not letting it open the door. But not allowing closing it? What other function is there? There isn’t one. And it doesn’t make sense that it’s a safety issue because if I can tell Alexa to close the door in my house, I can do the same from the app Inside my house without looking at the actual door. So this is very much false advertising that it works with IFTTT because it doesn’t. There’s only two options to a garage door: to open or close it. I understand why you wouldn’t want an Alexa with no security to be able to open the door, but not being able to close it? Then there is 0 function you can achieve with this. It makes no sense. You guys need to remove that it’s functional with IFTTT because it’s clearly not. And when I asked the technician why not, he told me it had nothing to do with MyQ and was a IFTTT function (which I don’t believe because IFTTT wouldn’t disallow it unless given an order to by The makers of MyQ.)

This gets a solid 3 from me.  With some software updates, I think it could easily be a 5.First off, installation was incredibly easy.  A lot of these solutions require tapping into the wires for the button on the wall.  Great for older units but not newer ones with smart panels.  This one mimicked a remote control which is pretty handy.  Instructions were great and it was like a 10 minute install in total for 2 doors.

I had to return the My Q. Just didn’t work as advertised. I had no problem installing, using the app, or connecting everything to WiFi. My main issues were with the Bluetooth door sensor and the god-awful warning alarm that blares like your house is on fire when the garage door closes.Door sensor: other reviewers have stated existing LED lighting can really interfere with Bluetooth - and they were right. The door sensor was placed correctly on the inside top of the garage door, about 15 feet from the main unit mounted on the ceiling. The pre-install pairing of the two units was flawless (when they were 3 feet apart). The farther distance once installed proved too much. No connection between them when the overhead LED lights were on. With the lights off, if worked fine. My LEDs are controlled by a motion sensor switch - which is more important to me than a dark garage. With the door sensor not connected, I could still open and close the garage door remotely with the My Q app, but I would (obviously) not get the door open or closed status and the subsequent notifications that would have been useful. According to the app, my garage door was always closed.

I recently bought the MYQ-G0301 Smart Garage Hub and that comes with one sensor, but I have two garage doors. So this is an easy way to add another sensor.At $32 it may have come down from the original $50, but it’s nearly as much as the $38 special offer for the hub (which includes one sensor).

Absolute garbage, just like everything HomeLink-enabled and Chamberlain-branded. If I hadn't gotten this on a good sale, it'd be going right back. The only good thing about this item was that the directions were easy to follow and it was relatively easy to install, as it should be, since it's just a Bluetooth module that detects the state of the door to the Wi-Fi module.The device itself is decent looking, though I wish it were white so it would match better. I thought the light on it would be useful, but it turns out it just flashes along with some really annoying beeping when operating the door, and there's apparently no way to turn this off. Turns out that doesn't matter to me anyway because once I got it set up the first time, it randomly operates the garage door (i.e., closes if open or opens if closed) once every hour or two. I reprogrammed and tried again, and the issue continued. I reset it and currently, it's just an expensive sensor on my garage door with alerts to my phone, which is better than nothing, but the open/close functionality I'm leaving off until I can figure it out to not have it randomly leave my garage door open. Lots of troubleshooting says to remove anything with frequencies that could interfere with signals, but that's just not possible and not an acceptable solution anyway.

Two or three time a year I drive away from my house forgetting to close my garage door.  Never again!This device will send a notice to my phone if the garage door is left open for more than (I picked 5) minutes.  Then I can close the garage door from anywhere using my phone.

This was easy to install, took maybe 20 or 30 minutes and works well through the myq app but further integration is going to be hard for people that arent too savvy with smart home stuff. IFTTT is now free (at least for a limited time) so you can connect this to location services and smartthings with a little extra code written by the smartthings community. I was able to get the door to automatically close after I leave my home and automatically open when I get close to my house but it's not super reliable, but I am still doing my testing and tweaking. I am super surprised that there is no direct alexa integration through a skill but if you have smartthings you can work around the no skill for myQ by using virtual switches from smartthings in alexa. Just search google for this and you will find it.This is a nice option for the price (I got it for only 20 dollars) but if I paid full price I would be disappointed however I do plan in keeping this for now at least.

This seems to be a great product. I have two that have been operating perfectly for three weeks now.  One in my home and another in my shop.  Installation of the first one took about 15 mins including watching the great video from Chamberlin. The second took maybe 10 mins.  I did have to reposition the hub in the shop because I didn’t follow the instructions that clearly say to place the hub away from large metal objects. I initially placed it behind a large machine because there was an unused outlet there. I had connection issues until I followed the directions and moved the hub to a more suitable location as advised by the instructions.  No problem since it was moved.My daughter and son in law have purchased one after seeing me open the house door from my Apple Watch when my keys and phone were 250’ away in the shop.  Theirs’ has worked perfectly as well.

Waited 2 months before reviewing to make sure none of the concerns I read in other reviews materialized.  Having read about importance of garage WiFi signal strength, I purchased the TP-Link N300 for additional $seventeen to max out the signal there - which as a bonus, increased WiFi range in my yard for using my buds while working outside.  I use the MyQ at a basic level - open/close 2 doors, with corresponding notifications, and remotely confirm doors are closed.  No schedules, etc. - my life's just not that complicated.Everything's worked perfectly following straightforward install (be sure to watch online videos which help significantly).  A couple of layers of hockey-stick tape over the crazy-screechy alarm softens it enough.  With two doors, I needed a second door mounted sensor.  During holiday sales, the entire hub/sensor combo was only $six more than the individual sensor, so I bought a second combo package and now have a backup hub for only $six.  2nd sensor synced just as smoothly as the first.  I didn't find the hub proximity to the 2 sensors as "sensitive"  as some reviews described.  Sensors are between 8 and 10 feet away from the hub with no glitches.  I think these are a good value for the cost and effort.  Would recommend to family/friends.

Installation was fairly easy but I had difficulty pairing the MyQ Smart Garage Hub with my 1993 Craftsman 139.53628SRT garage opener. Multiple attempts failed to pair after choosing the Green button learn option. The most helpful reviewer mentioned a maximum limit of transmitters the opener can handle so I reset the opener but the hub still did not pair. An answer to a question mentioned that he tried choosing Chamberlain instead of Craftsman and Yellow button instead of Red. I tried that and the opener light flashed a couple of times so it seemed I was making progress. Went back to choosing Craftsman but Yellow instead of Green button: still no pairing after choosing Green the light flashed a couple of times again. The green "pair mode" light in my garage opener turns off in about 30 seconds, so every attempt to pair I did set the garage opener to "pairing mode" multiple times while MyQ attempted pairing. Finally, I remembered a video at support(dot)chamberlaingroup(dot)com/s/article/Why-won-t-the-MyQ-Garage-Wi-Fi-Hub-open-or-close-my-garage-door-1484145690679#gdo-not-working  (view the video in the support article "The Smart Garage Hub or MyQ® Garage won't open or close my garage door " or watch the "myQ In-App GDO Pair" video in YouTube. The video mentions that an LED light bulb can interfere. The bulb in the opener was not LED but I removed it anyway and LO AND BEHOLD the MyQ hub and the opener paired almost immediately. Remember to use your MyQ username & password to login at the MyLiftmaster(dot)com and set up alerts. I also added MyQ to the Amazon Key app. Note in the photos that I placed the sensor diagonally opposite the hub, but it is no more than 13ft away. The sensor should be placed on the same side of the garage as the hub.

This is a great product if you have an older garage door opener with no wifi connect capability.  The app works well.  Installation is quick and easy with the app and the videos included.  This will work with almost any garage door openers that have the infrared safe closing sensors at the bottom.  Basically, it connects as another door remote control that you can control via wifi, from anywhere.  The app tells you if the door status, open or closed, and for how long it has been that way.  You can set of a schedule from the app.  After much research, I have found that IFTTT and Simple Commands have limited to almost no integration with this device.  Alexa, at one time, could be set up to control this device with limited functions, using IFTTT or Simple Commands.  However, almost as soon as this is coded by users, it looks like Amazon comes up with an update or something that prevents this.  It is common sense that giving Alexa access to opening and closing your garage door is a security risk.  Amazon does not want to be responsible if a burglar yells, "Alexa, open the garage door," through your closed windows and cleans you out.  It works will with the app and if you get a IP camera installed in your garage it works a piece of mind.  Good product but is basically stand alone at this time.  I like it though.

Update Sept. 28, 2019Rating reduced to 3 stars. I continue to be disappointed with the integration with Google Assistant so I contacted Chamberlain via phone and online chat today. The human on the phone was nice enough to tell me that the function to open the door is disabled because there is a security risk that anyone be near an open window and with a Google device nearby can say, "OK Google, open my garage door" and it would happen since Google cannot do voice recognition reliably enough. Fine, but state that clearly in your propaganda, Chamberlain. I received similar from a chat session with a human (I forced it out of the AI chat and to a human). That person made it very clear to me that nowhere on Chamberlain's website to they claim that MyQ and Google can OPEN the door. You can check the status and you can CLOSE the door via Google Assistant, but you cannot OPEN the door. But they don't point that out, and they should. I had never tried to close my door via Google / MyQ, but I verified today that that does indeed work.

I lost one of my garage door openers and instead of buying another one I decided to buy this so I could open the garage door from my phone.  It was a pretty easy install and everything was working fine until one day while going for a walk and I stumbled across a mother bear who was not happy with me.  She started running after me so I took off, running faster than Bruce Jenner on a Wheaties Box.  Finally I get to my house, thanking God that I have my phone to open my garage door. I open the app and boom the app didn’t have anything on it, my garage door opener wasn’t there anymore.  Luckily as soon as I crapped my pants the bear lost interest.  But after unplugging and plugging it back in it started working again, but I learned that it can’t be trusted and I always need a backup

Pros - I installed everything in less than 5 mins.  If you can navigate a cell phone you can install this.My Deatails - I have a Liftmaster garage door opener that is less than 5 years old.  It is on a standard two car garage door

Awesome product. Have you ever driven off, got 5 blocks (or 50 miles) from your house and thought: "Did I remember to close my garage door when I left?". I've done that several times and had to drive back to make sure. Well, this gadget (and its' Android and Apple apps) keeps you from ever wondering about that again. The app notifies you that the garage door is closed, or if it's open because you forgot to close it. If you did, just tap the close button in the app and the door closes, no matter where you are as long as you have a signal on your phone. Plus, it gives you a time notification each time you use it. A great use I have for it is that we have to leave our little dog at home sometimes and for us, four hours is the max we want to do it. Using this we don't have to remember what time we left the house, and our dog. It's right there in the app. It is a bit of work to do the install (which is why I gave it four instead of five stars for that), but there are a couple of excellent install videos (links in the install booklet) that show you how to do it. It's been in for several months now and works flawlessly. Highly recommended.
Think this product is Great!  I wanted it for a couple of reasons:1) My wife and I have turned around numerous times to ensure that we had closed the garage door and

Had a couple false negatives in the beginning. It made my not trust it. I went out of town for a day trip and when I was on my way home. Happen to look at the app and it says my garage was open.  My neighbor says he never saw it open.  Thank goodness. But of course I was checking that nothing was missing. Alarm logs said it wasn't opened either. But the sensor suggest it was. Anyway now I have warnings through my alarmTo let me know if it was left open. Just in case. Hit close door on app and it refreshes the sensor and verifies the door position.  But now makes me want a camera to see what's going on in my garage too now.

I have a detached garage so my alarm company wouldn't install a sensor in is so I needed a way to make sure my garage had some type of security. This along with a Wifi camera gives me the ability to know 100% that my garage is secure. The installation was pretty straight forward, I watched the installation video which helped a lot. The only issue I had was that with the Hub mounted on the ceiling of my garage, it would not connect to my Wifi. I have a Wifi radio in my garage that shows the Wifi signal is maxed out, So I know the signal is good, however the Hub just wouldn't connect. Could have been interference from the LED lights I have in my garage. I remembered that in one video I watched the person making the video said that the Hub could be installed on the wall, so I gave that a try. And just like that, the Hub connected to my Wifi right away.  I really like the fact that It sends me notification when my garage door is opened. I also like the fact that I can open and close the garage door with the app, I've been known to leave my home with the garage door open.  I cant speak for how it works with Alexa because I don't have any of their devices and even if I did, I wouldn't give anyone access to my garage.I do recommend this product.  So far so good.

The thing is absolutely terrible.  App login takes too long - even if you don't sign out.  The app notifies me well after the door has moved (I'm talking several minutes, & I have notification set to immediate).  I previously was using NEXX & it worked flawlessly until it broke.  I would rather have nothing than have the MyQ.  I was in the garage, & had been for over an hour when I was notified that my garage door had just opened.  It hadn't moved.  Also, I understand the audible alarm - but a means to control if, & how long it sounds would be nice.  I read where people silence the alarm by opening the MyQ hub & either removing the internal speaker or filling it with glue to stop the noise.  Also, we sometimes like to have the door partially open for ventilation.  Can't do that with MyQ.  Pressing the Open/Close button while the door is in motion confuses the app, & it then becomes necessary to use either the wall switch, or the vehicle remote to cycle the door & reset the MyQ.I would NOT recommend this app to my worst enemy.  I will be selling my MyQ on ebay when I return from an upcoming trip.  I will be replacing the failed NEXX unit with another one - like I should have in the first place.

I have used and installed many smart home devices, including lights, switches, curtains, universal remotes, you name it. I've come across bad, cheap low quality Chinese devices that require so much effort to install correctly. I'm also a software engineer, so I can sometimes make things that are not supposed to work, work. Unfortunately, MyQ-G0301 is the worst of the worst. I gave up with this device.The hardware is cheaply made, with very poor quality, and not reliable at all. The software is poorly designed, with ridiculous user experience and no proper error handling code.
The MYQ-G0301 is a nice economical unit.I just installed it today, so I have no long term feedback.

Pairs easily with router.  Door sensor works perfectly to tell you the door is up or down.  Here is where installation gets tricky.  Directions say to plug in your HUB at a work bench or a wall plug and pair with your garage door opener.  Mine worked fine pairing like that but would not pair if I mounted it to the ceiling first.  Then it says after testing mount to the ceiling 4 to 6 feet away and wrap the extra power cord around the mount to hide it.Mine stopped working the moment I mounted it on the ceiling and wrapped the power cord around.  Then when I thought it was a pairing problem I tried to re-pair the HUB to the opener and it would not do so.  i gave up after 15 tries.  Then I tried moving the ceiling mount.  No dice.  I took it down and was going to give up.  Then I thought about it after a week..........  the HUB is a radio transmitter.... radio transmits up and out not down and in.  If you mount the hub above it it will not operate the opener.  I brought it back down the bench, it re-paired instantly and worked every single time.

If you are unfortunate enough to start with a Liftmaster or Chamberlain "MyQ" garage door (that does not have WiFi) all you have is a totally unnecessary security protocal MyQ invented to keep you from using competitors with working. reliable free integrations that also allow opening.  But it's not MyQ because that would suggest it you know has MyQ built in.  You still need to by and internet hub.  39.99 or 79.99 to make it actually MyQ.  So they put the MyQ logo on to trick people into getting the secure device is all.Opening is blocked for "security".  I don't know why they have claimed a stake in protecting MY garage.  The certainly don't have stake in protecting it with their standard garage door openers.  MyQ, your role is to provide the open function (I'm sure at a cost) and a disclaimer releasing you from all responsibility.  And allow me to OPEN and close my garage as I determine works for me, with notifications, cameras, integrations.  See were not stupid.  We got this.

After waking up several times and finding we forgot to close the garage it was time to get this gadget.  Or we drive off and my wife says "did you close the garage?" planting that seed of doubt so I would have to turn around and go back and YES I closed the garage!  The marriage is saved thanks to this gadget.  First, install the mobile app BEFORE you begin installing, there are videos that walk you through everything, the printed instructions aren't really meant to guide you through it all.It works with almost every garage door, they have a compatibility chart on their website if you have any doubt so check your make/model there before ordering.  There is no cutting or splicing of wires, you plug it in, that's it.  The only challenge is finding your "pairing" button on your garage door opener motor.  You'll need a step stool or something to reach it.

Setup failed at the start in connecting the myQ hub to the home WiFi. The myQ app got into a forever loop. The phone needed connecting directly to the hub's WiFi, and then setting up the home WiFi info from a local page. I checked the online support pages, but the info to solve the problem required chatting with a human agent. It was quick, and they were helpful.After that hiccup, setup sailed along, as the app guides you through the whole installation process. The main use case for me is setting up the schedule so that at 10PM the doors are closed. My wife has in the past not closed the garage doors overnight. Even her mom worries about that when I travel. So this way there's no problem.

SUPER easy to install. We still use garage door openers and have alarms and all of that.  This is very convenient though to know when the garage is opened and if you forget your opener or do not want to carry it. I loaded up the how-to video on my tablet and it literally took me 10 minutes.I initially had the senor paired onthe garage door but onthe other side from where the sensor is and I had some issues so i moved it to the same side. I inititally did not want it on that side because I have other sensors but so far no intereference.

This is a much cheaper option than replacing the entire opener to get a smart option garage door opener.  We use our garage door more than the front door, and there is always the question, did we remember to close the door.  Now I have peace of mind on my phone.  The one thing I want to add to the review is how the device actually works.  It is actually a simple solution.  I thought that this wold attach to the garage door and fully integrate with the existing opener.  It doesn't.  Its a fully wireless system.  There are two parts to the system.  The first one plugs in to an outlet in the garage and then wirelessly syncs to the opener just like the keypad you have outside of the garage.  The second piece is a sensor that just attaches to the garage door with double sided velcro.  The hub can attach to two garage door openers, you just need to add a second sensor for the second door.  The sensor just indicates whether the door is up or down.  I wish I had known this when i ordered because I would have ordered two.  On black Friday they had the hub unit on sale for less than the extra sensor, if you can catch that deal take it, then you have a spare hub, but the sensors would sync to either system.  Great product.

I've been holding off on this review, waiting for Chamberlain to email me back about my issues, but they haven't, so I have to give it the lowest rating possible. Basically, it works great overall. I love being able to view the status of my garage door, as well as open or close it remotely. It's also nice having another way to open my door as a backup in case my battery dies on my keypad.The biggest issue with this product is that the sensor gets stuck from time to time. It seems to happen more frequently in cold weather. Basically, you'll close the garage door, and the app will think it's still open. The only way I know for sure is to check a camera I have pointed at the door. Since it happens frequently enough, but sporadically, I can almost never trust the status that's showing in the app, particularly if it says it's open.

I got this because my old garage door openers are not working, and to replace then was gonna cost almost as much as this system.  I have 2 doors, and they are old, but are compatible with the MyQ.  I bought the basic system and then an additional sensor.  I got everything installed in about 45 min.  I am a single female and not super tech savvy.  The instructions were adequate, but the videos and corresponding slides after were frustrating cause pausing the video did not work so good.  The system worked from the beginning.  I downloaded the app before installing, and then the Amazon key app.  It has only been up and running for 1 week, but no issues yet.  I have had one in garage delivery from  Amazon, and it went without an issue.  I will need to add a friend and family member so they can use the app to open garage if needed, this is much easier than having multiple openers that may stop working. (that is what happened).  Time will tell if this system will be safe, without delivery persons taking things when dropping off packages, or after.  It is unclear to me if the device they use to get in the garage is available to drivers not working.  That is more of an Amazon key issue though.  I will update as I use the app and device more.

First things first: if you, like me, saw that this integrates with Amazon Key and therefore assumed it would work with Alexa, here’s the key point of this review: it absolutely doesn’t.  There is an integration with IFTTT you can use to have Alexa close the garage door, but not open it, and because it’s done through IFTTT, you have to use “trigger” in the voice command, which is clumsy.I had really hoped this would work like August, where it will close by voice on-demand and open by voice with a PIN code challenge.  Sadly, this is not the case.

It's yet another garage door opener that works using a  smart phone. Easy install - seems to work OK, but.... We bought this thinking Amazon would finally deliver our packages into the garage instead of just throwing them over the gate, stacking them outside the gate - and generally refusing to ring the doorbell too. Stuff gets stolen around here - as it does everywhere - and we thought, "This solves lots of problems." Nope. First notice we got with our next purchase was that only slower deliveries get the MyQ treatment that uses the garage door. My wife asked, "Why? We're Prime Members and everything... Why would they NOT want to deliver them more securely?" Why indeed? Guess we'll return it. We don't need it to open the garage - we have, including the car buttons, a dozen buttons and remotes already, plus remote access cameras with motion sensing to tell us when the door opens/closes. Waste of $45.00 and an hour and a half of our time. Makes no sense. Too bad.

I have two Chamberlain garage doors so I bought the main unit, which comes with one door sensor, and then an extra sensor. I had a garage door opener at my last house that had MyQ integrated into it, and I love being able to control and monitor my garage doors remotely. So I bought this as an add on.The product design is good. If it installed without any exceptions to the process, I would have given it 5 stars. Now that it's installed, it seems to be working great. But getting it installed required a lot of trial and error and frustration. Indeed, I thought I was going to have to send it back, but I perservered.

I had no issues installing it- I followed the tips posted here in other reviews, and it worked like a champ right away. (Too bad the Chamberlain documentation does’t include these tips!)My one concern is the sensor you mount on the door- why does it use such a tiny battery?  It uses one of those button batteries.  How long  will it last, I wonder?

Ok first off this is SUPER easy to install.  My garage contains the router and modem, so wifi signal was not an issue.  I used the included velcro to attach the door sensor to the garage door (easy).  The iphone app makes setting up the myQ hub to your router very fast.  For mounting I cheated, rather than making new screws on my ceiling I just zip tied it to the mounting rails of the garage door opener.  Overall installation took about 15 minutes, very easy.Now I know everyone complains about the IFTT integration being a subscription and I agree.  Chamberlain are greedy, and you should NOT sign up for that service.  That said I wish there was ANY Alexa integration.  ANY AT ALL.  I don't need alexa to open and close my garage door, but I'd like to be able to ask alexa.... "Alexa, Is my garage door closed?".  Considering this is just about the only add on that works with Amazon Key I'm surprised they don't even have that level of support.

I got this from Amazon Warehouse and it works fine at my vacation home on an AT&T hotspot.  First thing, I did a hard reset right out of the box to clear any other user setup info.  I had to make 2 attempts to get it to connect to my hotspot router and I had to be very very patient.  I had 2 bars of wifi on my smart phone at the garage.  I have this working on a 12 year old Craftsman door opener.  Pairing/learning with the garage door opener took apps 8 attempts.  Instructions say "TRY AGAIN" if learning doesn't work, so I did.  My guess is many users give up and don't persist 8 times!  The system has been installed for one month with no problems. I can open and close the door from 70 miles away to let the contractors in and I can also see when the door is up if someone uses the keypad or button inside the garage.  I have not activated the Alexa capability yet, I don't see needing that, but I will try it just for fun.  Overall this is a good product.  It plays well with 4 other Wyze cameras and Wyze door sensors on the same hotspot.  I have a pretty good security system setup on a $30/month hotspot versus $70+ for a standard broadband connection from the local telco.  Keep in mind, as with any gadgets connecting to wifi and routers, expect problems. These are complicated systems with many interactions and the manufacturer can never anticipate all of them.

I have been using this device for about six months now.  I almost tossed it in the garbage after the first month.  It seems that when this device fails or has an error, the default action is to fail open.  Like I had mentioned, we were using it for a month with no issues.  We had gone out for the day and the neighbor noticed our door was open, but the car was not home.  They let us know and I attempted to close it remotely and it would not close.  I tried three times before the app told me that I needed to manually operate the door.  After we got home and used the wall switch to close the door, I attempted to open it remotely, it would not work.  Had to do a factory reset on the device to get it to work again. We have been using it since, without any further issues.  I set alerts in the app to notify me as soon as the door is open now as a precaution.  I can understand why the app developers set this device to fail open, as they do not want you to be locked out of your garage, but it is a bit of a security risk when that does occur.

I've wanted to add some type of smart home integration to my garage door openers for a while and finally pulled the trigger once the MYQ-G0301 dropped below $60.  Two months later, I bought an adapter for the second garage door (another $30) and now have both garage doors controlled via app.There are some things I love about this.  First, Amazon now delivers packages to my garage.  We've never had a package stolen off of our doorstep, but somehow the Amazon delivery drivers give at least one of our packages to a neighbor at least once per month (we usually receive 5-10 packages from Amazon monthly).  Because they now use Amazon Key to deliver our packages, they see the picture of our garage door and have to open *our* garage door, which prevents them from leaving it with a neighbor.  I don't think we've had a misdelivered package since installing and that would probably be worth it alone.

Snap to set up.  Didn't even bother with the mount.  I applied a heavy duty adhesive to both devices.  The powered sensor and the one instructed to apply to the garage door.  I live in Vegas, so this will be a true test of the adherence of the strips.  I have a range extender, with my wifi.  So, if YOU don't and if toi DO and its NOT configured properly.  It's really NOT the manufacturer's issue.  Hopefully their TS, will get you guided in the right direction.Out of the box and operational, it was a breeze.  It's day one, and things are working great.  Very lame, they offer sync'ing with Google Assistant, but for now (July 27, 2020) you must got through the app.  My phone, using the Google Assistant, recognizes my device, and the status.  At the time of my post, the door was closed.  I repeatedly, asked the thing to OPEN the door.  But, it was having none of that.....

I've wanted garage door integration for a long time, and this device is a pretty cheap way to add it. I had to move my wi-fi network extender a little bit within the house to get the recommended 2 bars minimum in the garage, but this wasn't too bad. However, I'm dinging a star for these parts of the installation experience:- The instructions in the paper vs. in the app don't match, I hate it when companies do that. Are there different teams working on these? E.g., paper instructions said to pull sensor tab first, then install the app. The app does a walkthrough then tells you to pull the same activation tab you already did earlier

If you can follow simple instructions, you can install this with your compatible garage door opener in half an hour. The myQ app used to control it also walks you through the setup in very clear and concise instructions. I haven't seen another device with an app that has such great step-by-step setup instructions. That can't be said for their website unfortunately.The product works as advertised. What the description doesn't say online is the very loud beeping it will make when you ask it to close (and not very quick to do so). It is a safety measure, but I'd really like the option to turn the beeping off. The integrations with other services wasn't straight forward. I had to find a website to "purchase" these integrations such as Google Assistant or IFTT. Even though they were free "for a limited time" that doesn't give you any confidence they will remain free. Keep in mind these integrations are only for checking on door status or closing the door, never opening it. The Alarm.com integration must be done by your alarm installer and may also disable myQ app integration.

I don't like my current smart opener from Nexx Home so I bought the myQ system. One of the biggest reasons was because it "works with Google".However it doesn't actually work the Google. After a fair bit of searching on how to connect the accounts I was successfully able to link my Google and myQ accounts. I finally try to open the door with my Nest Home Hub and myQ through my smart speaker says "For security reasons I cannot open the Garage door". I feel the "works with Google" written on this product page and on the box are not genuine and is false advertisement to lure people into buying their device over others. Now I understand why they're giving away the Google integration for free. CAUSE IT DOESN'T WORK ANYWAYS!

It wouldn't pair with my door motor, but a call to there support team had it working in no time.  They were very good at supporting the process to get the hub working with your lift motor.  High praise from me.  Its been an extremely long time since I was impressed by a support person.  I assumed i would have to send it back after i couldn't get the door to pair with the control hub for close to an hour.PS.  The most important part is to mount the door sensor on the door prior to setting it up.  I didn't want to mount it in case I needed to send it back.  Tech had me tape it to the door temporarily and that was the issue.  The hub needed to sense the door opening after it gave the command.  Since it was just sitting upright on the workbench it failed.  One other thing, my learn button looked grey or white to me.  The choices of button colors to push during pairing are Yellow, Green, Blue, Purple and Red, no grey or white.  I must be color blind as the tech looked the website and saw the frequency of the door motor and said I had to choose purple button on the list.  I had already tried all the colors, and in hindsight only the purple choice had the door move.  That should have been a clue prior to calling them.  But the sensor wasn't on the door so it failed on that one too. :(

After using this for several months I'd say this is better than nothing but has issues.  I have 2 of these and have installed them on 2 separate doors.  One door is rarely used and this unit seems to work perfectly.  My main garage that gets used everyday, fails to detect that the garage is closed about 30% of the time.  So I'll leave in the morning, using the normal openers (not MyQ), and about 30min later I'll get a notification on my phone that the garage is still open.  I've since put a camera in the garage to double check and so far this notification has been wrong 100% of the time.  So MyQ thinks the garage is still open, so I use the MyQ app to close the door which then causes the door to actually open.  MyQ then detects this as a fault and shuts off remote access, so at that point I'm away from home and have no way to close the door.  If I ignore the 'door still open' alert then many hours later it'll properly detect the door as closed.About a month ago I used the support form on the MyQ site and still haven't heard back.  I've gone through the troubleshooting steps they listed and in each case the test was successful.

I bought Chamberlain garage door opener with MyQ, thinking it works remotely using WIFI, but after installation found out that my particular model, although has MyQ logo, needs an extra gear (MyQ Hub) to work with home network. Models must have both "MyQ" and "WIFI" logos to eliminate the need for MyQ hub. Anyways since the opener already was installed in my garage, I ordered MyQ Hub. Installation instruction does not exist and if you try to follow the App to set up, you will most likely get to a dead end. I had to call the customer service, and promptly got help to finally install the hub and get it to work. There were several steps going back and forth from the app and the web site. So I hope Chamberlain fix this unfriendly install process. After installation it works fine. when closes using the app, opener makes a loud beeping sound that is very annoying, it might wake neighbors up if i use it late nights or early mornings to close the garage door.one last positive point was that customer service was very friendly and helped promptly to setup the hub with home network, otherwise i would give it 0 starts.

I installed this opener solely so that on those days when I drive away from home and wonder "did I shut the garage" I can check...and shut the garage if I did forget to.I've found some other benefit in the product. It's nice to know when the door opens and closes using notifications.

I was really looking forward to this device. I use Google Home products throughout my house and I have been searching for a automated garage door opener that would integrate with these devices. Unfortunately, at this point in time, MyQ is NOT that device. I realized shortly after receiving the MyQ that it only integrates with Google ASSISTANT and not Google Home. This is definitely frustrating. Even after installing Google Assistant and signing up for the subscription (which I also didn't realize was necessary, but is apparently "free for a limited time"), through the MyQ app, I can only CLOSE my garage door with voice commands. This makes ZERO sense. When asking Google to OPEN the garage door, it tells me that it's unable to do so "due to security reasons." After doing a bit of Googling, this seems to be a pretty standard problem and it is with MyQ and not Google Assistant. Basically, this significantly limits the usefulness of this device and makes me regret purchasing it before Chamberlain figured out their own product.That said, installation is pretty straightforward and after fussing with my garage door opener (not a Chamberlain product, but listed as compatible on their site), I was able to get it to work properly. I can both open and close the door from the MyQ app.

I have two garage door openers - one is a newer Chamberlain model that is MyQ enabled and one is an older Chamberlain.  The internet-connectivity has come in handy, for example, was able to have a friend stop in and pick something up for us while we were at the beach several hours away and they were joining us there later.  Also nice for kids to be able to open without keeping a separate opener in their cars or if they're getting dropped off by a friend.Was excited to find this Hub deal during Prime days and it works great now that everything is connected.  Most of the install was easy to follow through their app, including wifi setup, but I ran into a problem pairing to the opener.  Here's where I deducted one star.  Tried multiple times to get hub connected to opener with no luck (spent maybe 30-45 min trying), ultimately got frustrated and tried to call their support and was on hold 25 min before I hung up, their chat support feature didn't work, so I defaulted to email.  Well intended email response a couple days later asked for info I already provided, like opener model.  Couldn't find any hints online for this specific issue but thanks to another reviewer Steve, I tried something different that worked.  He mentioned, and I'm paraphrasing, that some older openers can only remember a limited number of connected devices.  How I solved my issue was erasing all prior codes (hold down the learn button for ~10 sec), basically starting from scratch.  I also cleared out all the old device attempts in MyQ app, not realizing I had created duplicates.  After starting over, pairing the hub worked perfectly and I had things up and running in less than 5 min.  Had to reconnect car homelink buttons, portable openers, and keypads but they all work now.

Got this on a deal primarily for the ability to alert and close my door remotely at night. The app works well and can be scheduled to either automatically close the door at a certain time, or to send an email/push notification if the door is open/closed/stopped at any time. The app is free and no additional services are required to do this scheduling.Setup was a breeze. I followed the instructions, which really just meant powering things on and mounting them. The on door sensor must have an acceleromter in it to know if it's facing up (when door is closed) or horizontal (when open) and it was easy to stick on with the included two sided tape. The hub plugged in and took about 30 seconds in total to get it on my wifi, I have both 2.4ghz and 5ghz, and it only works on the 2.4 so be aware. This is fairly typical of IoT things though, so if you have other devices no big surprise. Mounting the hub is also pretty simple, just two screws and it's done. The directions have recommended spacing of where to put things, I loosely followed them and have no problems.

Editing to add one star because there is an Alexa workaround available, although I’m not sure MyQ should get the credit.  The MyQ app works with the Simple Commands app and Simple Commands works with Alexa.  So now my phone tells Alexa when I’m arriving home, Alexa tells Simple commands, Simple Commands tells the MyQ App, MyQ tells this hub and this hub tells my Lift Master opener so that my garage is fully open by the time I reach it with my car.  Essentially I got what I wanted but it’s more complicated than I expected.I think the listing is misleading, this works with Amazon Key so I assumed it worked with Alexa.  It doesn’t.

Bought a Smart Opener to monitor my garage door while away as there has been questionable openings of the garage door.  I had a nosy neighbor who monitored my every move... he used to call me if my garage door remained open!  The nosy neighbor recently moved so I lost my surveillance and needed an alternative watch system.Selected MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener Chamberlain MYQ-G0301  based on reviews and known compatibility with my Chamberlain opener... and the price is unbeatable at 25 bucks.

The connection and linking from the Hub to the door sensor and the mobile app was very fast and the instructions from the app were intuity and easy to follow, in fact I recommend using the app over the enclosed papers because it has prettier pictures and videos!Linking it to the garage door of the same brand was tricky and it took me multiple attempts because my wifi signal would drop after the whole configuration was successful. This would cause the sensor to go on monitor only. After some moving around I found a good spot about 3 feet away from the garage door opener where the wifi signal was greater than 65%. Once the wifi signal was obtained setup and linking to the door opener only took seconds and a single try.

I was able to get this device hooked up so I could use my phone as a garage door opener.  It does work, in my case it took some fiddling around.  The initial set up was to download the app and install it near the garage door opener.  Fortunately for me, there was an open outlet in the ceiling right next to the garage door opener.  The first attempt was frustrated by a weak wifi signal, so I installed an extender and it works pretty well, but it certainly doesn't replace a simple garage door remote.  Imagine the difference of pushing a nearby single button on your remote/car or whatever other device you use to open your garage door and finding the app on your phone, letting it open the interface then pressing the soft button in the center of the screen.  Sometimes it will open right up and work, other times it will go to a different screen so you can update and/or save the configuration.  The good thing about this is that you can open your garage door from a greater distance than a typical garage door remote.  Is it worth installing on your phone? YMMV

I hesitated getting this with all the 'have to subscribe' to add Google Home support comments. I read I could get a 2-month trial of it - but I never bothered with Google.  Once it's on your smart-phone (my android and wife's iPhone both) - you don't need anything else.It's great - and works, I'll get a buzz and notification of 'Door is opening' or 'Door is closing' - I can then load my cheap remote cam app and see who came or left.

After reading another review with lengthy tips regarding installation I was a bit worried, but I decided to give it a try anyway. As it turned out, installation took seven minutes from the time I opened the box, and the unit has worked flawlessly since then. My garage is fairly close to my router, so signal strength wasn't an issue. Also, I realized that the hub doesn't need to be mounted up on the ceiling next to the opener. The installation pictures show it up there, but maybe that's because that's where the power outlet is in many garages. Anyway, I just plugged the hub into a wall outlet in the garage and it works fine -- no issues communicating with the opener, which is about 12' away. As a result I didn't have to mess with a ladder, and didn't even have to mess with the mounting bracket, since the hub just sits on a shelf near the outlet. Couldn't have been simpler. The unit synchronized with my opener with a single button push. Since installation a couple of weeks ago the system has performed reliably. It allowed me to open the garage for the AC repair guy when I wasn't home, and reliably alerts me every time the door goes up or down (the settings are customizable). Overall, a great convenience. UPDATE, ONE BIG NEGATIVE: After being installed only a few months, I received an alert that the battery in the door sensor is almost dead. The sensor uses a button battery, which is kind of crazy. Why don't they put in real batteries that will last a while? This is especially a problem if you have a seasonal home and plan to use the MyQ to open and close the door for contractors when you're gone. The battery won't last long enough. Big flaw in an otherwise excellent home automation system.One last note: Never buy this system at full price. It goes on sale periodically with deep cuts in price, so wait if you can.

Bought this because I wanted to be able to open my garage door if someone came by and I was away.  I didn't care about the Amazon Key, but since the price was right, I got the garage door bundled with the camera.I read many reviews on different products and because of the price went with this model, knowing there were some limitations to use 3rd party apps, at least without a charge. (I do think this is a shame, but good marketing I suppose)  To use with Apple HomeKit, you have to buy an additional expensive Home Bridge, which costs more than the door opener!
TL:DR - I bought the MyQ system to couple my garage doors to the our smart home (Google Home). I have been underwhelmed. Look elsewhere.The Good:

I was hesitant about buying this product after reading so many reviews with one stars but I went ahead and purchased the MyQ product hoping this hub would allow me to monitor my garage door thru my cell phone and alert me when the door was left open.I have an Orbi router with three satellites that broadcast a strong internet throughout my house, garage, and front and back yard.  I mention that since I feel a strong internet signal is essential to making this product work appropriately.

I've had this installed for about a year, and it's worked perfectly the entire time. There's a lengthy review below by a "professional installer" that describes all sorts of difficulties and calamities. It took me - an unprofessional installer - all of 3 minutes to set up two garage doors. It worked great the first test, and hasn't had a single issue since.They recommend installing the hub on the ceiling, but I was able to get a strong, reliable signal with the hub attached the wall near the outlet it's plugged into. I've not had one instance where there was lost signal, I've had no false alarms, no random opening or closing... It's just been rock solid and very helpful to have.
I was looking to solve my Amazon package delivery challenges and by and large, I found it.Once installed, the system works well and does exactly what I was hoping for.

First, I woke up the other night and had left my garage door open all night by accident. I could have been robbed or worse... not a good feeling. Second, I got my parents one and I've had one previous that I left in the house when I sold it. I went looking at other options but this one was the cheapest, I thought (see cons below), and I knew it and had used it so felt good about it. It also came with Amazon Key (which is useless unless you have a camera or just want to trust blindly that someone is going in your garage to just leave the package... Sadly you have to pay for Alexa, Google and IFTTT integration (hence 4 stars) which is just unheard of and ridiculous. I'll buy another brand next time due to this.Pros
Can't beat this for 60 bucks with the add on sensor for a second garage . A breeze to install and convenience on your cell with the touch of a button for one or 2 garages.1. Make sure door is closed.

Got it for $30 on Amazon Prime Day.  It was easy to install with the instructions.  I didn't attach it to the ceiling like it says to do.  I just set it on a shelf in the garage, but it works great every time.The only thing I didn't figure out before buying it is that you can't tell Google Home or Alexa to open the garage door.  You can tell it to ask MyQ to close the door, but not to open it.  I understand that based on security reasons, but there should be some sort of override for that if you're willing to accept it.

Very easy to install. Took about 10 minutes. I had no issues with connecting to WiFi. But everyone was right about connecting to Google Home/Assistant.  HORRiBLE!! They need to do a better job with connecting to Google Home. Luckily it's not a must for me. It would have been nice to have voice control and that would make it a 5 star. But only gave 4. Works great with my garage. Definitely recommend it. Gives alerts when door is open/close and history. I like that. But if connecting to a Voice control App like Google Home is what you want. Don't get it. Otherwise it's a good product. Although I did not have to pay the subscription fee. They were running a free offer. When you use Google Home it goes to MyQ app then you have to the door. They need to work on the integration with Google Home. Didn't use Amazon Alexa, so can't say how it works. Otherwise great product. Of course I just hooked it up, so I be giving an update in about 3 months if all is still good with it.

I give MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener Chamberlain MYQ-G0301 a five-star rating for these reasons; 1. Simple setup - no need to disconnect/connect any wiring to the garage door controller. 2. Works instantly and from anywhere if your cell phone is connected. 3. It seems more reliable than Z-wave Garage Door Opener – I owe a GoControl/Linear GD00Z-4 Z-Wave Garage Door Opener Remote Controller and many times it fails to open/close the door. 4. Easy sharing with up to five guests – no need to share account password. 5. Standalone – no need for additional smart hubs.Improvements I’d like to see? Lacks the ability to open or close the garage door to a specific height. My garage faces towards the west and can get hot here in in South Florida during the summer months. During the day, I like to leave a small crack under the door so as not to trap the heat…MYQ-G0301 will either fully opens or fully closes the door.

Buggy at best.  Easy to install, set right up.  Worked great for 3 days, then it lost the link between the app and the hub.  Go through the steps again, neither sensor will bind to the hub (I have two doors - bought two hubs not realizing one hub can control multiple devices).  Neither hub will bind to its sensor.  An hour on the phone with Chamberlain - no luck.  He mentioned "oh, you bought it on Amazon?  No wonder you have problems."  - not buying it, they all come from the same factory.  Decided it must be the (brand new) batteries in the sensor.Unplug the hub, move it to another location - no luck.  Put the hub on the floor - ding!  it worked.  But it won't recognize when the door was opened/closed through something other than the app - like the button on the wall.

I couldn't figure out the Genie Aladin setup even though it was compatible it just looked like too much work to install so I instead went with this route and the setup took less than 10 minutes.  I didn't feel comfortable mounting it to the roof of my garage so instead I used Command Strips to stick it to the wall in the garage near the AC.  I didn't have to align any wires on the ground or mess with my garage unit.  it was simple and straight forward setup.  Make sure to watch the setup video it's super cheesy but it highlights all the important pre-work you have to do before setting it up.  If you want it to work with Apple HomeKit, you need to get the Chamberlain Home Wifi hub ($69.99) and then it will work with the MyQ and by using the Hub you can then use CarPlay and open your garage door from your car..  SWEET!  NO REGRETS!! THANK YOU for makng this super simple!  If my ADHD brain can do this, so can you.

I read the reviews on this, and wondered about the various negative reviews that have been left on here. Thankfully, I can say that my experience has been nothing but positive. My garage door opener is a Chamberlain, so the MyQ is automatically compatible. However, if you have a different brand, there is a pretty huge list of compatible openers on the MyQ website.Anyway, installation took me about 10 minutes, including dragging out my ladder to reach the ceiling of the garage where I installed the hub, and cleaning the dust off the spot on the garage door where I mounted the sensor. It all worked right away, since the garage is directly below the room where my WiFi router lives. Honestly, the only difficult part about the installation was dealing with the cobwebs that I kept getting in my hair up near the ceiling.

The product was very easy to install, took me about 30 minutes to get it working correctly. It was a life saver when we had it operational.I had set a schedule to automatically close the garage at night if the door was open. Tonight that worked against us.

I am the ONE person in all the world who owns an incompatible garage door opener. If you have Mannetec, even a recent vintage (mine is 2013) this will NOT work. Mannetec does not broadcast a pairing signal in the right way for the Chamberlain system to pair. It took hours to figure this out. I did also actually have a defective unit (according to support) the first time around and returned for a second one. However I now think the support person just couldn’t figure out my opener was not compatible. I intend to replace one of my openers with an actual LiftMaster (ugh also made by Chamberlain). I found it incredibly annoying that my opener was not listed as incompatible. I really wanted this for Amazon deliveries. The app does work great and seems like it will integrate with Alexa seamlessly. I’ll know more when I get the new opener installed!

Yes, it's easy to install.  But after that, my experience was all down hill. I had expected integration with Alexa, which I found out is not available. I received an email from Chamberlain's tech support indicating that they are "evaluating" integration with services such as Alexa, but have not determined whether they will ever support it.Get with the program, people. What is the most popular home automation service?

This product surpasses all of my expectations. I have a bad tendency of leaving my garage door open when I go to bed so I was looking to find a product that would notify me if the garage was left open. I stumbled upon this for $30 and I couldn’t believe all the things it could do for ONLY $39. So I decided it was worth a shot. I got the device in the mail, unboxed it, and had it installed within 15 minutes. I didn’t think it would be easy or even work because my garage door is so old. But it worked, the very first time. I have had the device for about two weeks now and it has really surpassed all expectations. I would have paid $100 for this thing.The things I like about this product:

I have a 1993 Liftmaster opener. This was a 15 minute install. Check the MyQ website for compatibility before you buy.The app from Chamberlain walks you through the steps. There are even videos showing you how to do everything. Well done Chamberlain.

I purchased this system to accommodate a second opener on a second garage door. I just had an Overhead Door brand Odyssey 1000 (model # 7030) installed. This door opener was built in 2020 according to the serial number (which started with a “20”). When I called to discuss my challenges with Chamberlain they informed me the newer door openers aren’t compatible. They said Overhead Door has created their own product that competes with Chamberlain and the new openers were no longer compatible. So this product was easy to set up and operates my 2002 Overhead Door “Phantom” opener just fine, but it won’t touch the new Odyssey. I even tried another owner’s workaround that was posted here and it seemed to pair the opener, but it would not operate the unit. So bottom line, it only works with my 18 year old opener! Hopefully that old opener has another 18 years in it...

While the device picks up our WIFI better than most devices, our garage is so far out I had to add  some parts. It was a bit unstable due to the WIFI signal being a little weak. I added an Ether Net over power set and then put a wireless access point in the garage. Now that it is getting good signal it works as fast as my regular clicker and is more stable than my ancient wall button. Also since I used to forget whether or not I close the garage and would have to double back to check, I have peace of mind and have not had to double back once since I installed it. Now if I could just get the Amazon delivery drivers to follow instructions and put my packages in the garage I would be very happy. But that is not the fault of Chamberlain.I would like to see all of the instructions before starting. If those could be added to a web page and the URL put on a card in the package that would be great. They are in the App but I like to see what is next and it keeps me from making mistakes when I see ahead just a little. IE I mounted the device a little far from my opener and the found the 4 to 6 ft step in the App.

It works perfectly, no complain about how easy it is to install. One tip though is to set up the hub and pair the garage door sensor before trying to put the sensor up on the top panel of the garage door. The instruction tells you to just put the sensor up first, but doing so making it more difficult to get paired with the hub. So when I'm done setting up everything, the last step says to put up a safety sticker, that's when I realize this thing will by-pass the safety sensor at the door which detects a subject intruding the path when closing and triggers a reversion to stop or open the door (instead of closing it). Well, that's a big concern to me because I have kids around the house, and so safety is always my concern. So now I trade off the worries about whether I close the garage door or not with the worries of somebody might get hurt when i press the close button on the phone. Such a nightmare! So for this reason I would never dare to use the scheduled closing. Also the app does not automatically send you any alert, you need to go in and set up alert such as garage door was closed/opened and etc. Anyways, i figure the current remote system is not a pain, so i still mostly use the physical remote and myQ will come in handy when I am not physically around or when i need to open the door for somebody else w/o moving my a**. But then again i just feel like it does not make much sense for myQ to completely ignore the safety sensor detection.

I like that it acts with the existing equipment, wall opener, remotes, etc. With our older Chamberlain opener on the door.It was pretty easy to setup and configure once I figured out that my wireless repeater was not working after a firmware update.

Like most things this works if you understand your needs and match them to the product features.  It is not the ultimate remote garage door management system but is very capable of managing a standard 2 door setup and the price was very attractive.I have a Linksys mesh wifi for the house and it provides a consistant signal to the hub.  I do have some 30 wifi devices in the home including several things like wireless speakers and wireless tunable LED lights in the garage but none have caused any issue with these devices.

I wanted to get this a long time ago but back then it was about $40-50.  I just saw it on sale recently for only $20 so I finally bought and I could not be happier.  It took me about 10 minutes to get everything installed and another 10 minutes to install everything on my phone.  I saw some reviews that indicate it does not accurate work for them but I been using it a week now and it is 100% accurate so far.  I have the Chamberlain garage opener.  I am easily able to open the garage from my phone and know when it is open.  I also love the feature that I can give access to other people.  I like this feature because when my wife and I are traveling I can have one of my friends come over and they can put any package/mail in my garage while we are away.I also setup it for Amazon Key because I order from Amazon at least 8-10 times a month.  I wanted the key option for any electronics/fragile items I order so I know that it will be safely placed in my garage.  I just scheduled my first delivery using the app so we'll how that goes.  Overall, this product is a must have.

If you don't have a camera in your garage, get one because this device wont put you at ease. I bought this assuming 1 it would work with Alexa, it does not(at least to my knowledge). 2 I thought I'd be able to set up a garage door open timer, not an option, you can set a schedule where it shuts at a certain time of day, but that's about as advanced as it gets. 3 A few times so far I've shut the garage while parked next to the garage, and the door didn't close, but the app was not sure if it was open and closed and asked me to visually inspect it... Good thing I was next to it, if i was across town how would I be able to do that? 4 a notification is great, when you're looking at your phone, but what would be better is being alerted it's open, that you accidentally hit the button or someone has broke into your garage and opened it.. I want to be ALERTED, I want ALEXA to tell me, I want my Firestick to shout it. Even if you ahve a camera, unless you're altered there's no reason to check things out unless you have a suspicion

I'm glad I can open and close my garage door now using my Cell phone, from anywhere.  I also set up 2 Timers so that at 8:15am and 6pm my garage door closes ... in case I have forgotten to do it myself.But mostly I bought this so Amazon could stop leaving my purchases on my front porch in plain view.  Since I received and installed this piece of Hardware, Amazon has only used it once.  I've had at least 10 to 12 deliveries since then.
