I think the Amazon drivers just don't want to leave the street and drive around to the alley where my garage is.  So for that reason, it's a FAIL and why I gave it only 2 stars.

I have a liftmaster garage opener that is 3 years old. With yellow light. I actually don’t need a sensor, just the Hub!I was following the direction and was not able to pair the system with my garage door. After 5 times, I contacted the MyQ support team via text. That is when he (Wesly, and he is awesome) told me I don’t need the sensor at all, and the sensor is keeping me from pairing with the garage door. He walk me through the setup, first clear the hub memory due to I tried 5 times. After clearing, setting up was quick. on MyQ app, click on left hand corner, under device manager, choose light control, and followed directions, finally it WORKED!! So I am done with set up with MyQ support. I can now open and close garage door with MyQ app.

Installation is straightforward - but do be sure you follow the instructions.  Importantly - make sure that the location where you initially program the device and where you plan to mount the device have strong to flawless WiFi connection.  I suspect many issues reported with the device are the result of WiFi connections that are poor or failure to follow the directions.Setup did NOT go without any hitches at all - but - the biggest delay was that I initially pushed the wrong button on my opener.  My (Wayne Dalton) opener has a black button on the back of the motor with several LED lights - and that was the wrong button!  Once I used the Purple button on the side, the unit programed without issues.

I was reluctant to purchase as some of the reviews indicated installation difficulties.  I can say the installation process went off without a hitch.  To start I followed the instructions provided in the box then followed up with the app to complete installation.  I have a Craftsman door opener with the purple button with three remotes and one keypad being utilized. The app is easy to use. What compelled me to purchase was Prime Day price discount. The two features that I like most 1.) Set up a schedule to open or close. There's been times I've forgot to close the garage door at night. Now it will automatically close. 2.) Because it's a nature of habit to push the button to close when leaving home but you get down the road and can't remember if you did or not. Now just look at the app. Really happy with this purchase.
I can’t believe the negative reviews....maybe they are from a Chamberlin competitor?There is NO FEE. don’t know what these guys are talking about.

You can only open the door through this hub with the MyQ app on your phone. If you attempt to set up Google Assistant via voice command to open it, it will only tell you the door is closed. It will not open. However, it will close via Google Assistant voice command. How helpful is that? I wanted to set up a geofence using IFTTT so that the door would automatically open while coming up the driveway or close itself when leaving. Opening while coming up the driveway is not even an option and I haven't gotten the close part to work yet either. But the not being able to open either with IFTTT location or using Google Assistant is a deal breaker. I've got to find an alternative wifi controller.

I love this device! So easy to install!  I don't understand any of the reviews who act like its a big deal. Install it as instructed and you will not have a problem.  Got it for Christmas and installed it the 26th. Took about 25 min, but I took 10 mins to make 2 wooden blocks for the door sensor to mount to the metal angle iron (did not trust double sided tape) and the same for the smart hub (see pictures).  I simply loaded the app and followed  the instructions for Iphones.  My Lift Master door opener is 22 years old with the Red button, you only push and release!  holding it will erase all your other programed openers and you will have to put those back in.  I leaned this many years ago adding a new car.I set up the alerts for when my door is opened!  Very handy if my kids swing by, I can then check to see if was left opened.  I have a pick up truck parked in the driveway which I pull away and have left the door open, not good!

I bought one of these for my Dad and then had to get one for myself. I ended up installing them both because my dad was put off by the instructional video (he didn't want to spend the time to watch it). I didn't watch the video I just followed the installation instructions that came up (first thing) when I first opened the app. The instructions were easy to follow and everything installed quickly and easily... for my install. My fathers install took longer because the app didn't show it finished connecting to the unit. After waiting 20 minutes I unplugged the unit and started over. It then connected pretty quickly. I think it had connected because the unit led wasn't blinking but... well.  Anyway, I enjoy being able to see when my garage door opens/closed (letting my know when my son gets home) and being able to close it if/when he forgets to. One irritation was the alarm that goes off when closing. After my father closed his door the alarm continued for at least 15 seconds or more. I do wish the alarm stopped when the garage door opener stopped. That's my only complaint.

Update: Yeah, I tried to switch my router, and my smart hub failed.  It keeps saying "this serial number does not match the hub" and "cannot connect to server"... even though it was on my other router 2 hours before!  Now my device is not even recognized.  Chamberlain Support was not even helpful.  If you never need to touch this ever, it's good.  If there are any changes, good f'ing luck.I bought this MyQ Smart Garage Door Opener because the range for one of my garage doors dropped so much that I couldn't even open the garage door from the outside with multiple remotes and I also tried changing batteries.  This solves that problem because it uses my wifi network to tell the MyQ opener to open the garage door from the inside and it's closer to the antennae.  I don't need to try and resolder the garage door opener antennae, lengthen the antennae, drill a small hole into the garage door so I can get an antennae through, buy a new garage door opener when mine is mechanically sound, etc.

This company seems to be the WORST! First of all, it's NOT compatible with Wink as advertised (The entire reason I bought it) secondly the "Support" team does anything BUT support the customers, it's been nothing but runaround and BS from the reps. I'll be looking for a refund and possibly a class action lawsuit.Oh yeah, you can't open your door using IFTTT or Google home, only Apple Home Kit. They're trying to charge a subscription fee to use it as well. Just SOOOO out of touch with how this tech is coming to market.

The remote would raise the garage door, but would not lower the door. All TECH REFERENCES said it was due to a misaligned safety device mounted on the bottom of the door frame, but... I made sure the lasers were aligned and it still did not close the door, so... I went to Walmart, bought a new battery for MyQ door opener remote and now it works as advertised. I don't know why people are bitching about subscription fees, I installed mine with an additional garage door remote and HAVE NOT SIGNED UP FOR ANY SUBSCRIPTIONS. I have opened and closed my garage doors from deep inside of the outback of Death Valley, California and watched the doors open and close visually via Arlo and WYZE streaming cameras, also with no subscriptions.

I had asked my local garage door company if they could add the MyQ feature to my existing opener. They said that I would need to install a new opener for $500. I took a chance and bought this product instead and I am glad I did. There was an addendum to the instructions for an IOS device that required me to connect to a WiFi signal from the device and open a web page in Safari to connect to my network. That went well and the only glitch was pairing with my opener. While the button on the back appeared to be red, it was actually purple. That took several attempts and had the effect of disabling my other garage door opening remotes. It was easy to reconnect them. I used to forget if I had closed my garage door but I don’t have to worry about that anymore as the MyQ app on my phone tells me if the door is open or closed. This is a great product and saved me $400.

Kind of cumbersome, slightly a pain, could've been so much easier.At first the setup did not connect to my garage, I did manage to wipe out all the programmed controllers while following the apps instructions though.  Turned out I had to ignore the instructions in the app for my model, which is listed as compatible.  Then it finally started working.  Features are: open and close...

I would suggest that you exactly follow the instructions step by step to make sure you have a successful first time installation and set up. I have an MyQ Chamberlain garage door opener so was disappointed that could not use it as is to remotely control my garage door. The options were to purchase either the Home Link or the Garage Hub. The Home Link would connect directly to the MyQ garage door opener and make it a smart device and is compatible with Apple devices, however, I would still need an additional add on device to add my second garage door to the group, besides that the Home Link is being offered at a higher price than the Garage Hub which is compatible not only with the MyQ but with most other garage door opener brands and models. The MyQ app is free to download and use and currently the Google Home app and the IFTT migrations are available at no cost but no option for Alexa connectivity, however, the Amazon Key and Amazon Garage is also available among some other options for no additional at this time. I am connected to IFTT and Google through my MyQ App and that is great to use, however, I won't be willing to pay any monthly fee if Chamberlain later decides to start charging for these options that are free with other brands and providers. Until then, I would recommend this device!

Update #4. The new bulbs worked perfectly! Great stuff and figured out what was messing with my wifi signal as well.Update #3, i ended up ordering the TORCHSTAR Garage Door Opener bulb and so far its working fine for me. Ill update again later this week.

I'm writing this review in hopes that Chamberlain will read it and make the relatively simple software changes that would turn it from a 3-star to a 5-star product. Anyone buying this device would want it to integrate with their other "smart" devices and home security systems and this is where it falls short. There is no integration with Alexa, Siri, or Apple's Homekit. There is an app for your iPhone but you can't say "open door" and must use your hands like an old style clicker. If you don't have Face ID enabled, you must enter a username & password before pressing the "open" button. Time consuming & tedious. Likewise, you can't ask Alexa if the garage door is open or tell it to open for someone while your hands are busy. I would also like to see an app for my Fitbit so I could use that to open the door. Another feature that is strangely lacking is rule based commands. For instance, I would like to have a rule that states "close the garage door if it has been open for 30 minutes". There is an alert for this situation, but you have to see the alert and close the door manually. Conversely, there is a scheduling feature that doesn't seem useful. Who opens and closes their garage door on a regular schedule? On the plus side, it did install and connect to my network pretty easily and does a good job of alerting me when the door is opened or closed. I have used the Amazon Key delivery service with it and that works well. It's just odd that Amazon endorsed this product that doesn't work with Alexa when there are others that do. I believe all of these issues can be corrected fairly easily with software so I hope Chamberlain will do that work and send out the updates that will make this a 5-star product. If that happens, I will happily update my review.
First of all, once I got everything to connect, it does what I want it to do.  Connecting everything was not so easy.1.  Hub easily connected to WiFi.

Overall, my experience with the Chamberlain product has been very good, but with a couple of exceptions. The WiFi-enabled portion of the system works very well, after a few installations (software, not hardware) issues. The real problem has been in trying to link the system into HomeKit. After a couple of days messing around with it, I finally gave up on getting the HomeKit hub to work, and now it's sitting where it's mounted on the garage wall unplugged and acting as a wall decoration. Trying to get the HomeKit integration to work was probably the most maddening thing I have done in several years. Not only did it not work, but it hard-crashed my Apple HomePod so bad that I had to unplug it and not only reboot it, but go through a entire re-install of the system. After going through it a couple of times, I had had enough, and now there it sits.I _do_ like the WiFi enabled part of the system. It works flawlessly, and I use my iPhone and Apple Watch to open and close the door. It just doesn't have the HomeKit integration that I originally thought I needed, but now see that it may not be that important.

This could not have been simpler to install and get working for a single user.As for setting up multiple users, that’s pretty easy, but they sure missed the boat on security best practices. You can grant open/close access to “family”, “friends”, or “other”.  Sounds good, but I can’t tell the difference between which privileges each group gets. I wanted a family member to get notifications when the garage door opens or closes, but that’s not supported. Only the original account holder can get those alerts. Or, share your login credentials with somebody, then they will also get the notifications. So much for the accountability part of security. Sharing credentials? Bzzt.  Thanks for playing, we have some lovely parting gifts for you. Tech support is prompt and helpful, and they say they’ve passed my security suggestions to the development team. I hope there’s an app update to improve the security features soon.

Installation was super easy and the video instructions are great. It'd be hard to screw that up if you watch the videos.The worst thing about this system - and something that is incredibly frustrating - is that it is not compatible with Google Assistant without a paid subscription. My $8 no-name Chinese smart plug integrates with Assistant for free. It's embarrassing that Chamberlain MyQ doesn't offer this same basic functionality standard.

I replace my door motor because the old one broke.  The new one was not compatible with all my clickers and keypads.Instead of replacing them all, I bought the smart door opener so that all my family could use their phones to have access to the door.  It was less money, and more convenient.

I've installed 3 of these units so far, one in my sister's garage, one in my parent's garage, and in my garage. The first two worked fine, no problems. They have average length 1 - 1.5 car garages, but I have a longer 4-car garage with two doors and it's not working well for me. One hub can control two sensors, so I bought a second sensor. The hub, sensors, and openers need to be fairly close to one another (like under 10') for them to work correctly. I've yet to get them working consistently well. Support is mainly via India chat (aka. a joke). Phone support wait times are infinite. If you have a larger garage, think twice before ordering.

I did not notice until after I had ordered this on PrimeDay that there is an additional fee for Google Home integration. I planned on returning it, however once I received it I opened it up to "play with it" a bit before sending it back. I noticed a "Limited time offer" of free Google Home. I still had to sign up for it through the App but it was free and it worked So I went ahead and installed it. The install took about 30 minutes. I did not mount mine to the ceiling but simply put it on a shelf in the Garage and connected it to my WiFi. Everything is working Well so far. Hopefully they make the limited time free Google Home and IFTTT integration permanent.Things I dont like -

I had to go to the website and review the manual and even then had some challenges getting the Hub to pair with the garage door opener. The open is a fairly new Craftsman (Chamberlin) with the purple "Learn" button. I had no trouble pairing the door sensor with the Hub and no problem getting the Hub on my network. But using the phone app to get the Hub to pair with the opener was time consuming and a pain.  The phone app also would appear stuck in the pairing mode for several minutes and wouldn't come out of that gracefully. I expected a timeout or some indication that it wasn't successful and allow me to retry. I finally gave up trying to pair with the Hub to the opener after several attempts and had to get the Craftsman manual out. I found that the Craftsman wired wall mount opener also had a "Learn" feature on it. I was able to use that part of the garage door opening system to pair with the Hub (first try). I have no idea why pressing the garage door opener Learn button would not allow the Hub to pair.The other issue I had was trying to set schedules. I wanted the door to open automatically at 6 a.m. but for security reasons, opening via the schedule isn't allowed. I tried multiple times to have is close via the schedule at 10 p.m. in case I forgot, but the phone app repeatedly stated there was a problem with the door opening and it had to be reset by using the actual garage door opener to cycle the door. Multiple times I would reset the door and reschedule but I got the same error. I've had no problems using the app to open or close the door by tapping the app Open/Close button.  Not sure why the scheduler isn't just issuing the same command in the code as touching the Open/Close button on the screen.

I am delighted very well by this product so far with 3 days using experience.  The installation process is quite easy and they have a clear instruction to guide you step by step, as other smart home devices do.  The pairing process to my old lift master door opener is amazing that I didn't think it would be so easy and it does. After set up, the device is ready to go.  However, at the beginning I was a little bit surprised as it doesn't fully support Alexa. And the MyQ skill in Alexa was not there anymore therefor I tried IFTTT first, but the company only allow you to close the door with voice but not open due to security concern.  Totally understood but still not happy until I found simplecommands which allows me to create use sense and linked to Alexa for voice control, open/close with my secret words.  It works well now and I am quite enjoying to ask Alexa to do this new home feature everyday.

I wanted to physically harm the people who designed this product when I first tried to set it up. After weeks of not being able to set up the sensor, I decided to look up the model of my garage door opener and was devastated to learn that the color of the learn button was actually purple but apparently faded overtime and looked orange. All of those attempts were in vain because the button was a different color. I also realized that other peoples warnings of LED lights were not simply hogwash but actually true. When I turned off all of the LED lights I was at least able to get it to pair in “monitor” mode when I was still selecting the incorrect learn color. I would like to suggest that the makers of this item allow it to be programmed without the user being required to select the color of the learn button. I’m sure there’s a way to design the programming to allow that — to me, it is laziness. Other than that, the annoyingly loud beeping is the only nuisance that I experience when using the app. Its probably designed to prevent lawsuits.

The other day I was a couple of miles from home and then suddenly had the feeling I'd forgotten to close my garage door. I turned around and went home (the door was closed) and made it to my appointment a couple of minutes late. In talking to a friend later that day, I mentioned I wanted to get a surveillance camera so I could check on the garage door over the Internet. He told me his son had installed a sensor that worked with an app on his phone, and it was pretty cheap.Well, I got home and did some Google-Fu and found the MyQ for only $30. Unbelievable. I ordered it and it arrived the next day.

Instructions make you think that when you press the button on the door sensor that the red light should come on. Red LED only flashes once when you press the button.The first garage door I tried to connect to the system failed at least three times. The odd part was that the door would go up and down and function perfectly except the App on my phone kept telling me that it had failed. Turned out that the Door Sensor I had previously connected had become disconnected. So while everything worked correctly the App reported a fail due to not knowing that the door had come open and shut. Deleted everything and started over. The second time the Door Sensor stayed connected and the App reported the installation as a success.

I installed this pretty easily in about an hour, and it works perfectly. Some comments & suggestions:1. Clear hard-copy instructions would have been nice. Once I figured out that the Mobile app would walk me through the setup process things became easier, but I personally prefer hard copy instructions for multiple reasons.

This was SUPER easy to install and works perfectly. I have a Linear garage door opener (1 door) and it’s relatively close to my router. Setup was very easy and faster than I expected. Alexa doesn’t pair with it as far as I know but it does work with Amazon Key. I have not had any issues with it opening by itself, yet. But will update this if I experience anything like that.UPDATE. After having this for a few months, I will say that I have run into technical difficulties but have come up with solutions. Originally I had the setting to shut garage door at a certain time of night if open. This actually proved to be counter productive because as the battery in the garage door sensor starts losing juice it will actually fail to recognize it’s already closed and end up opening the garage and then glitching out and leaving the garage door open at night unless you close the garage door with original hardware. I’ve since learned to not enable that setting and also be conscious of battery health of the door sensor. Seldom run into issues after that though.

I have a genie garage opener so initially I ordered the genie Aladdin. I thought less chance of compatibility issues. But the more I looked into Aladdin. The installation seemed complicated with the Aladdin. Contrast that with myq, you don't hardwire anything. So i cancelled my Aladdin order.So glad I did. The myq is a breeze to install. I watched a YouTube before hand. But honestly, you could just follow the step by step instructions in the app.

I have two garage doors that I wanted to control. Neither have Chamberlain branded door openers, but both are on the compatible list. I ordered one for each door. The first few attempts by me to connect to my network failed and even with tech supports help, it would not connect.I left it alone for the winter and I had time to try again in the spring and still couldn't get a connection. I finally decided to try the second one I bought and it connected right away. Now I didn't need to buy two as both doors are in the same building and only needed the door sensor for the second door. While I spent a little more by buying to complete setups, I found a way to make it work.

Thebest  thing about this relatively simple little device is the peace of mind it provides,If you are always trying to remember whether you closed the garage door before you went to bed, of left on vacation,  this is definitely the ticket.

Affordable, work as intended with my 20 year old opener. The instructions give you the impression its plug & play, but it isn't. You have to press unmarked buttons on the device to locate wifi, sync it to your phone app, 'Learn' your garage remote signal in a particular order, none of which are listed in the instructions. Its basically just a parts list. I had the wherewithall to go searching via Google and found a Youtube video from the manufacturer. Why its not listed in the instructions is baffling... but that's the key to a successful install. Took all of 5 minutes once I learned the sequence things needed to be programmed. there is no camera with the kit, though I think you can purchase one...so it will tell you when it opens and closes via the app, and allow you to close & open remotely, but it won't let you 'see' the nature of the door [my daughter notoriously leaves it up], but if you aren't physically going back into the app to check the status, once its alerted you, it doesn't tell you its still up...but knowing I can put it down from anywhere is still a convenience I didn't have before the install. An alert sounds when you activate it thru the app, a safety feature so you don't close it on anyone, or give them time to get out of harms way.

I bought this specifically to be alerted when I leave my garage open by accident.  Installation was fairly easy.  It took a few tries to sync the door sensor with the hub, but it worked on the third try.  My problem is I am not getting notifications.  Not via email or phone which are both options.  I called two times today and both times I spoke to incompetent people guessing at answers without listening and stating them with conviction.  The first tech cut me of and told me I had to call Apple, it wasn't their problem and Apple must be blocking notification.  I am pretty savvy so I knew this was BS.  Asked how he explained no email notifications.  This stumped him and he back tracked, put me on hold for 45 minutes with no check in and then hung up on me!  I called back and got a woman who told me you only get notification of you open or close the door from the keypad outside the door!  You can't make this stuff up.  My case has been escalated to "tier 2" support.  Can't wait for their resolution.  Chaimberlan support for this product leave a lot to be desired.

From the product description, it would sound as though this thing connects to your garage door opener like a standard switch would. If it did work that way, it could actually be "universal". But in reality that is not the case.This thing works over RF, like your garage door opener remote (not the switch on the wall). Because of this, it only works with select garage door openers.

Installed the garage door opener yesterday in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions, and everything went smoothly. Once it came time to get it linked up to my Google account however, it became quickly obvious that this product's integration is either half-baked or deliberately disabled. I first looked through my Google Home app trying to find Chamberlain or MyQ to add a device, and was unable to locate either one. I eventually found the spot in the MyQ app to add connections "Works with MyQ" and then had to also download Google Assistant to my phone. Got them paired eventually, and asked google if my garage door was open."I'm sorry, it looks like that device is not set up yet"

The thing really is easy to install.  It took a couple tries to get the thing connected to my WiFi, but once connected it worked fine.  I followed the instructions on how close to have to the opener and where to install the other sensor and there were no issues with that.  Follow the instructions and test everything out before you mount it up.  Something I did notice about the app is it only tells you what it has done as far as if the door is opened or closed.  IE, if you opened with the app and closed with a vehicle remote, it will still say it is open.  It is not intuitive enough to know if it's opened or closed on its own, only what it has done.  We also have as of yet (only about a dozen tests)  to receive any notifications about the opening and closings.  Worst part is I added my son to my account and now he keeps messing with me and opening and closing my door from across the county!
This has been my worst smart home purchase so far, so I'm glad it was only $30. The Refoss Smart Wi-Fi Garage Door Opener is infinitely better, and here is why:Setup Experience:

Despite what you may have seen on Apple's website, this product *does not work with HomeKit*. And Chamberlain is more than a little deceptive about this fact - searching their support site for "homekit" reveals nothing about compatibility, but a great deal about how to set up other products that have to be purchased separately, in order to enable a feature that should be built into the product you already purchased. There's no technical reason that this product couldn't be HomeKit-enabled out of the box - but Chamberlain would very much like to sell you a separate hub for another $90 to enable that feature. I'm returning mine, and getting something else. Their smartphone app is fine, but also doesn't indicate HomeKit compatibility - despite having a screen in the app where HomeKit homes are actually pictured as available, you can't enable the opener the way you'd expect. As I said, more than a little deceptive here, and their product description needs to call this out clearly.

I set this up as remote sensor as I have a garage for a third vehicle. I like the fact that I only needed 1 MyQ hub to operate 2 sensors. It works most of the time but sometimes I get a connection error where it can't sense whether the garage is closed or open. This may happen more frequently if you use the car remote or the wall remote to open the door instead of the MyQ phone app.However best practice is to ensure that the sensor is within 15 feet of the hub. This second garage is perpendicular to the other garage where the hub is located so I'm pushing the limits of the range. If my set up was a tandem 3 car garage I'm sure it would work 100% of the time. So I'm only docking it 2 stars because of the range.

Update: After only 1 year, a ton of annoying issues have popped up. The coin cell battery on the door sensor had already ran out only 6 months, that's fine given that this is a smart device, but when I replaced the battery, it still kept showing as a "low battery" warning when I pulled the app up. Tested and tried other batteries, still doesn't go away.Next issue is that the door opener hub/app will randomly decides that it won't work. I believe this is on chamberlains end because when this does happen, my internet connection still works fine (can still browse the web and such, both from the home router and mobile data). When this does happen, you are SOL until it decides to work again (it was winter when I bought this device, it is also winter as of this update, and its freezing, any downtime is straight up unacceptable!)

Works well, but MyQ will occasionally get out of sync, not recognizing if door is opened or closed.I was successful integrating with Alexa and Siri. I did so by way of a 3rd party app “Simple Commands”. This app is free, no subscription.

The installation was easy and everything worked fine the first few days when I had it setup with a single sensor, controlling only one door. I added an additional sensor purchased directly from Chamberlain’s website for the second door. Installed it, the Hub recognized it, but since then the system behaves somewhat inconsistently for that second door. I thought it may have been a bad battery and I replaced the second sensor battery to observe how it works, it seemed to have helped but it is still inconsistent. I also tried to delete and re-add the sensor which did not help.Problems can be summarized as:

I've embarked on making my home a smart home and when I saw the functionality of the MyQ (including the ability to let Amazon put your packages in the garage), I was sold.  But I have to say I've been pretty disappointed and all of that disappointment is preventable and entirely Chamberlin's greedy fault.The device was easy enough to install as long as you get a good enough wifi connection.  I had to relocate my router to pickup the signal.  The device does work as advertised telling me when the door is opened and when it's closed.  It also allows me to do so remotely.  These are all great features.  That is where the greatness ends.

You screw or stick a little battery-powered sensor box to your door that senses whether door is open or closed by whether it is vertical or horizontal.  That door sensor connects to the other, slightly larger, box called the hub, by means of a wi-fi signal.  The hub connects to the internet by your home wi-fi.  The hub you screw to the ceiling near the door opener motor and it plugs into AC power.  The hub connects to the door opener just like the little transmitter you keep in your car by radio signal -- no wired connection.  You put the opener in learning mode just like you do when you get a new transmitter for your car.  Before you do that, however, you have to download the app to your phone and register yourself on the app.  Then the app finds the hub on the internet and takes you through the steps for pairing the hub to the opener.  Tip:  When you register it tries to put you right into a screen to do this.  It's better to get out of that screen and re-open the app to do this, using the "add device" routine.  Telephone tech support is good and I had no trouble getting through on a Saturday.  There is no monthly or annual fee for connecting to your opener through the app.  Once it is all set up, you can get emails whenever the door is left open for more than X minutes (you select X).  You can also set a schedule that will close the door if it is open on a regular timetable.  I set mine to close at 9 am, 9 pm and noon, just in case someone leaves it open and I don't see the email alert right away.  You can also check at any time to see whether the door is open or closed and you can open or close it.  An alarm goes off in the garage before it closes, as a safety measure.  And of course, your door should have its own safety system that would keep it from closing on someone (nearly all do, if not all).

I took advantage of the "limited time offer" of integrating with Google Assistant, using their (otherwise paid? no way...) service offer on their website.With Google Assistant, I have "Routines" configured that in the evening, locks all my doors, turns off some lights, and now - closes the garage door if opened. I can also tell the Assistant to close the garage door (though important distinction, you cannot ask it to OPEN the door, for security purposes.)

I have had a lot of trouble with this device. First off I had to give the device a static IP address or I got constant lag issues but that doesn't fix the Bluetooth connection from the door open/close sensor. I even had chamberlain send me another door sensor thinking that was the issue but it turns out that it's just bad design. I should have thought about the known interference issues that Bluetooth devices have. I even contacted chamberlain customer support a second time and received no help. I'm pretty sure the issue is that Bluetooth uses 2.4GHz frequency and so does wifi so they interfere with each other and changing the router channel didn't help me. I don't have any fluorescent lighting or other Bluetooth/wifi devices in the area.I would send this back but we already threw out the box. I should also mention that I'm an electrical engineer and still had all these issues.

I purchased this with trepidation fearing it would need wiring into the garage opener, and that I would need to follow wiring diagrams. In fact, it arrived with no instructions at all in the box!However, there was no problem. You just download the app on your phone, enter the serial number of the device, and the app walks you through everything step by step. THERE IS ZERO WIRING INVOLVED - IT JUST PLUGS INTO YOUR CURRENT POWER SOCKET.

Does NOT work.  Second unit I tried set up properly and I even popped to subscribe so I could use Google Home.  Right after I subscribed it was downhill from there.  You have to ask Google to ask MyQ if the door is open, then open or close it.  Sorry MyQ says, due to security it won’t actually open or shut the door.  Yes I set up Voice Recognition in Google Home for security.  So I’ll check the app for door status.  Server error.  Fine.  Wait a day.  Server error.  Deleted app and reinstalled.  Server error.  Attempted password reset.  After temp password received I tried to change password.  Another server error.  Fine,  I’ll just keep pasting in the temp password.  Server error.  Emailed support.  Answer:  your account is fine try again.  Days later same status.  Email support complete with screen prints of all error messages.  We’ll reply in a business day.  Four days later no reply.  Deleted app and unsubscribed and Amazon return initiated.  Feel free to repeat this process if you want.

Like the MyQ I replaced with this purchase it too randomly will work. It always opens the door, but has issues closing the door, and figuring out if the door is open or closed. No matter how many times I re-connect/re-establish the unit to WIFI it fails to close the garage. NO it is not the optic door sensors (common problem) because they work fine. The door closes using the OEM opener or wall button, or outside mounted remote. It fails just like the one I purchased in July 2019. Chamberlin will not even respond to my email inquiries. SAD JUNK.

tl;dr It does work after setup, but pairing to wifi was a pain, and the safety warning (beep noises) are extremely annoying.Install took about 30 minutes, and all because of app software / wifi sync issues.

Buyer beware. This product is defective. I bought it a month back and installed it with two sensors for a 2-door garage. Both openers are Liftmaster with Orange button. Initially, worked like a charm. Added Amazon Key capability and had a few deliveries inside the garage.Today, the Amazon Key delivery did not work. The app would not open or close the door used for Amazon delivery. Driver did standard delivery. Per customer service/FAQs, I deleted the second sensor and reprogrammed it. Now it was opening and closing both doors at the same time. Went thru reset-delete-app-re-install cycle 5 times. Same problem. Finally, I deleted one sensor thinking let me just use one door for now.

This product is well worth the price! Easy to install, works fantastic! Gives peace of mind to check the status of your garage door from anywhere in the internet world.  It is so simple and works so well that it really is a no-brainer! I like being able to open the door for a service person - I have a keypad and in the past I've had to give the code out, but this is a more secure way, plus you know exactly when they arrived and if they closed the door!  I plan to set it up to automatically close my garage at 10:00p.m. nightly, there is no worse feeling to going into your garage in the morning and realizing you left your garage door open all night.I totally recommend this and I absolutely love it! It took me under 30 minutes to install. My only issue with install and totally my fault is when I pressed the "learn" button on the door opener, I pressed too long and it erased all my other remotes which I had to reprogram.I would like to see Alexa integration, but that wasn't a deal-breaker for me, just a nice to have feature.

It was very easy to install AFTER I watched the YouTube presentation.  I would have gotten the same information IF I had completed the registration on my smart phone.  It would have been helpful IF they had said, "For complete instructions on how to install your MyQ, installing the app will lead you through the full installation process" or "Look at the YouTube video at ....."  Once I saw the video, it was a breeze to install and it works GREAT!  I like how I can open and close the door from my cell phone.  If I have someone stopping by when I'm not home, I can open the door for them!  If I have a delivery AND I can get them to call me, I can open and close the door for the delivery.  My only complaint after the install is that the notification that my garage door has opened or is closed might be delayed 10 minutes or more!  If I'm away from home and my garage door opens, I want to know it immediately!  Not maybe 10 or more minutes later, not when I happen to turn on my phone.  If I'm going to call the police, I need to be able to notify them while the person(s) are in there, not minutes after they have come and gone!  So, what is the delay?  Cloud issues?  Not enough head room on your computers/storage/program?  And YES, I would recommend the product.  I bet there is another updated version coming out!

What an infuriating system! I spent hours yesterday trying to get my Chamberlain Liftmaster Formula I to pair. I gave up after trying so many things and submitted for a replacement due to defective product. The replacement came today (next day, thanks Amazon!) and the same problems, but of course. But today I had an idea to not use Liftmaster but instead use OTHER and that worked! I pressed the orange button and as soon as it went out pressed it again. OTHER finally hit 3 of 11 (takes time) and that hit the magic code and it worked. Did this for both units. Trying to change Wi-Fi to another router is also infuriating as I reset the unit but it immediately pairs to the wifi you used before. Some people have multiple routers in their homes (I have 3) so you can't just reconnect to the same thing automatically. Whatever, it's done, it's working, I like having this feature on my phone to know if I left a door open and the other benefits. Setup is a bear, hopefully this tip of using OTHER will help you.

It does allow me to open the doors with the MyQ app. However, it doesn't work with Alexa and even though it claims to work with Google Assistant that doesn't work in a functional way (it will give status of the door sometimes but it won't accept any commands to control the doors. IFFFT worked though it was way too difficult to setup. And, they (Chamberlain) are saying they are going to start charging for the right to use this integration (which most every other maker is able to make work) which does not work for this product. Disappointed in the amount of money I paid expecting something more advanced but ended up with nothing more than a glorified app that barely works and only opens the doors in limited ways. Although it does work kind of ok with Amazon Key but sometimes the door doesn't open for the drivers which means they either have to leave it exposed for thieves or reschedule the delivery. Yep pretty much overall a fail.

Let's start with the home-integration elephant in the room: this kit doesn't support Alexa integration. If this is a thing you're after, look elsewhere. It does support Amazon Key, however, though I didn't use this feature myself, and can't report on it.If you're simply looking for a smart app for your iPhone or Android device that will act as an extra garage door opener, a garage door state checking tool, and a log of garage door state changes, this is a great solution. Easy to install, requiring only a power outlet and a remote digital "level" that attaches via Velcro (or screws, if you like) to your garage door. Ours installed in minutes, and works splendidly. Be aware that the system supports one master account and three "guest key" accounts -- if you plan to share access with more than four people in total, and individual accounts are needed, this may be a dealbreaker for you.

I got this because I often forget if I've closed the garage door or not, and it's a source of stress when I am away from my house. I was very happy with the hub initially, but I had a few glitches with the app not showing the correct state of the garage door in the month that I had it, which made me unsure if I can trust the hub.The App support FAQs were not helpful, so I finally called the MyQ Support line, and they helped me figure out the problem. It appears the hub was installed too close to the motorhead, which can create interference with the hub and thus provide false readings. The hub was installed by "expert installers" via Amazon, so I was a bit annoyed since I had to re-install / re-configure the hub myself again while MyQ Tech Support talked me through it (very excellent service, BTW).

I've been using the My Q app on existing doors (with Chamberlain openers) on my main house and have loved it. In an adjacent building I have an old Genie Opener and no reason to replace it but envy the notifications from the main house when a door is left open and the ability to open them remotely. When I first saw the MY Q Smart opener its price and the unknowing of how it would be compatible kept me at a distance. When it was available for under $20 during the 12 days of christmas it was a risk worth taking.Installing it took less than 30 minutes, programming it was a breeze and it even recognize the Genie opener without having to pair the with the remote.  At it current price ($29)it is a no brainer and even with the full price it can be a great control for any home. You can even operate two openers with one hub (Just buy the extra door sensor). Only thing I wish it had was a automatic door close timer. It supposedly works with IFTTT so I may create a program to achieve that. Just make sure you have strong wifi. Great Product.

Has great promise but poorly implemented and a bit annoying in operation.  In operation it's yells like a dying cat, but the software is the worst problem.  Just could be so much, but isn't.  Schedule is really lame.. ok. I can set a schedule for 10pm to close the garage in case it's open, but how about auto close the garage door if it's left open (like other non "smart" devices.  Also it seems like smart home integration (for me Google Assistant) is limiting to STATUS , and CLOSE.  You can't tell Google to open your garage door.. for "security reasons".  All in all just disappointed by what could be a great product.  On top of that,  an Amazon Prime delivery truck drew up with a package just as I was installing. The driver had never heard of the product. Said, "Only 2 companies in his warehouse use the feature" whatever that means.. so the main purpose of buying it,  having Amazon deliver packages to the garage does not seem to be universally supported.

Read a bunch of reviews watched a bunch of YouTube videos and decided to go ahead and see if this would work like some had said!I couldn't be happier! This was one of the easiest things I have ever installed!

Easy to install. Basically it is just another clicker, programmed into your exisitng opener. Connected it to my 14 year old and 20 year old openers. I did buy whole kit for each door, cause they were cheap. Took just a few minutes to make it work. Took longer to screw mount to wall then program. Note: I know how to install IOT devices and learned to keep eveything on your 2G radio, do not use your 5G radio during installation. After install move your device/phone/tablet back to your preferred SSID. Everything will work fine. Also, I just happened to have a Network Extender in my garage to provide steonger network to my driveway cameras amd fron door lock. Maybe $40 for the added extender, running on 2G , but I get awesome wifi in garsge area. Bottom line, this worked better than I expected, Works with Alexa. But I usually use the MyQ app, and skip Alexa.

This is super easy to install and does give accurate status updates on your garage from anywhere you can access the internet.  The remote control opening and closing feature is not as reliable as I had hoped.  I have had to unplug and replug it in a couple times to get it to reconnect and work properly.  Not exactly ideal when you want to use it to access your house.  Also, it has almost zero connectivity to voice assistants.  I paid to connect it to Alexa and all it can do is give a status of the garage and I think maybe close it.  It won't open the garage because they are afraid of having any liability if someone figures out how to hack it.  I find that frustrating because I was hoping to be able ask Alexa to open the garage if someone arrives.**UPDATE  After further thought I am even more frustrated with the fact this won't let me open my garage with my voice assistants (I have both Google and Alexa) simply because the company is afraid of that feature.  Paying to connect it is not worth it because I could just open the app to get a status update.  I really only wanted it connected to open the door hands free without getting up.  MyQ deserves a bad reviews for this because they completely avoid addressing this issue  and have made no attempts at fixing it or telling those of us with their openers already if they plan to fix it.  If nothing else, have people sign a release of liability if you are so afraid of people using the voice assistant to open the garage.

Installed easy enough, but Chamberlain forces you to take extra steps (namely IFTTT) to get working with Alexa.The door sensor is unreliable and uses an odd sized battery that isn't easy to find. When my battery went dead I ordered and replaced it, but it continued to tell me that the battery was low for several weeks. I did the "battery test procedure" several times but it took about 6 weeks to get it to recognize that I had replaced the battery... now the sensor will randomly stop working so the opener thinks the door is open when it has been closed, or that it's closed when it is in fact open... making it impossible to operate remotely.

The unit arrived on time and as advertised. I set it all up mostly inside (it's July and hot in the garage) except for mounting. I watched a couple of YouTube videos the night before the unit arrived. I just had to try to set it up to work with Alexa. I'm fairly tech savvy, but it took a while to figure everything out. Works great with simple Alexa commands: "Alexa open garage"...."Alexa close garage". I used the app "Simple Commands" with IOS (Apple iPhone). Overall happy with the product. Kept me busy during this "lock down"...

Installation was a breeze on my older (2008) Craftsman door opener, had it set up in minutes. I bought this because I always second-guess if I truly closed the door when I left. (prior to having this device I actually turned around and drove back home a couple times to double check; every time I found the door closed!)  Amazing product for the price. Now the downfalls...1. The light and horn on the hub are VERY annoying when you close the door from the app. I completely understand this is a safety thing but it would be nice to disable it.

Ok, my son did the physical installation, which took 5 minutes, but I handled the digital setup for myself, my husband and my son.  I’ll be 77 in a few days.  I can no longer drive a car, but I do ride a 4 wheel recreational scooter, and can go to grocery stores and shopping centers on the sidewalks as my personal highways.  I love being able to use my iPhone to open and close the garage door.  I have not yet used it with Alexa, but I’ll give it a shot soon.  I will also use the key feature for Amazon deliveries!  I especially love this to keep my cat from running out of the front door as I leave or return.  Going through the garage foils his escapes!

I e had this product for about a year and a half. At first, it was great. Worked wonderful. Then after about 6 months we started having issue. I blamed my wifi connection and tried resetting everything. That went belly up so I gave up, removed it and stuffed it away in my toolbox. Recently, my street had some vehicles get broken into. The thieves used the garage door openers tonipen a few garages. Eventually they stole my neighbors car and left. Well, that prompted me to want to install cameras and reinstall my MyQ hub. We also had installed eero wifi so i had a strong signal in the garage now. Reinstalled everything as if i was starting from scratch. Everything once again was working great. About a week ago i get a notice that the battery is low in the sensor so I get a new battery and change it. I do all the tests it tells me too and i see says it can take up too 6 cycles of the door to change the low battery message. Well, it's been a week, door has cycled at least 4 times or more a day, and it still says low battery. Also, it's not reading properly. Says door is open when its closed wont close the door when I press the button. This thing has been a big pain in the butt.

I've tried to set up the myQ account (name, location, password) and it only comes back saying the server can't be reached.  I've tried both using my wifi and direct LTE on my Google Pixel 3 FI. Same results. There is no option to set up the account through a PC web browser. A Google search showed that this to be a periodic problem, but I'm blocked from setting it up until this outage has passed.  I'll wait a day, but I'm already considering sending it back.Update:  On maybe the 10th try I got tired of typing/copying in the long complex password and so I just put in a fairly simple password.  It went right through.  I suspect that my "can't connect" error was actually a password it didn't like even though the web page said it was fine.  The next steps had no less than three different instructions on how to layout the hub and the sensor: one in the booklet, one in the app and a third one in a video pointed to by the app.  I now don't think the differences really matter but I mistakenly tried to reposition the door sensor due to the "new" instructions and messed up the velcro adhesives and had to dig up some of my own (which I luckily had).  Overall the myQ seems to work fine, but the whole process left me feeling less than confident that this thing will work well over time.

It does not work with Alexa, it works with Google (you can ask if your garage door is open or closed).  You can only open the garage door from the myQ app.  There is no feature for you to have the Garage door open automatically when you drive up.  Using IFTTT you can have the garage door close automatically when you leave home.  It's ok just not as good as I thought it would be.  That is probably why the price is so low.  The MyQ app allows you to set up a schedule and alerts so their app is useful send works well so far.Update 3 months later.  Well it's not working so good lately, sometimes it loses the status of the garage door (says open when closed, or closed when open).  Yesterday when I came home it did not record that the door was closed.  When I went out for a walk I had an IFTTT routine that closes my garage door when my phone disconnects from WiFi, since MyQ thought the door was open it executed the routine to close the door but since the door was already closed it opened it instead.  I thought this was a nice feature but since the MyQ does not track the state of the garage door accurately it looks like I will not be able to use it.

When it works , it works great and is a big plus in managing my garage doors. I have a three car garage with three separate doors. So I purchased two devices plus one extra door sensor (each device can handle two doors). It also offers integration with Amazon Key, an Amazon app that connects with myQ to allow packages to be dropped off inside your garage. And it will push notifications at once.Sounds great? Well, as long as the device stays connected to the internet. Sometimes, for no apparent reason, and I’m tech savvy, the device disconnects and won’t reconnect on its own. You are then left with starting the installation all over again except that it seems to retain partial information that interferes with a clean setup. I had to reset the device to factory setting and delete the app several times before it works again. That’s a hassle and a disappointment.

Really works great.  Able to open or shut the door from anywhere.  Notifies me when the garage door is open or closed.  Super easy to install and the step by step setup was the most detailed and easiest I’ve ever encountered.  Bonus is the Amazon Key integration, having packages delivered into my garage instead of left on my doorstep for thieves.  Just love it.Update:  It was super easy to add a "Guest" user with their own notifications and ability to open/close the garage from their phone.  As far as issues, sometimes the notifications seem to be slow, showing a much later closed time than reality.  In one case by several hours. The other thing about this and Amazon Key, without a camera it is hard to trust access to the garage so we disabled it just to be safe.  After we add another camera into the garage we will enable it again.  Its still a really great product and fully recommended.

The Chamberlain MyQ-G0301 works just fine in my Garage, with a so-so Wireless signal strength; it does just what I needed to use my iPhone to open and close the door (and the software indicates the current door position, and how long since it last changed).  The instructions and video installation files were very good and straight-forward, and I believe they helped eliminate any concerns I had for installing this device; it was especially helpful to watch the video 2-3x, to ensure I was familiar with the different terms and steps.  I did have initial Wireless signal-strength issues to resolve in the Garage, but the Hub locked up just fine on the Router's signal, and I did not need the Wireless Extender.The original price of the MyQ-G0301 is ridiculously high, but when it came down on 'sale' -- it was a more reasonable expenditure (still not cheap, but better than buying an entirely new Garage Door Opener); I see where the older MyQ-G0201 is less expensive, but my experience is to rarely invest in older models (although it may be just as good).  I have no desire to integrate this device with Alexa or Apple Home, and therefore I expect to never be charged any monthly fees that I read about in other reviews; if the latter is true, then I'm happy with this device's capabilities.

I am what the Spaniards call “not smart” and I had no issues installing this in less than 20 minutes. I mean, I own screwdrivers and a drill but rarely use them. They’re more to give off the appearance that I have a clue. Those that know me laugh when they see the clean DeWalt set in my garage.Nonetheless, I unscrewed a Mickey’s grenade and had at ‘er. Next thing I knew I was in my boxers gleefully opening and closing my garage with my brand new iPhone 5! #baller!

It's sorta there, but there are some strange implementation choices. For one, it supports Alexa key as a key advertising feature, yet it doesn't support Alexa native app. So I cannot build Alexa routines around this. To make things even more odd, I couldn't seem to get ifttt, Alexa, and MyQ to play nice together.Second, it doesn't allow for opening instruction to be given, at least that I found. I could close it and get it's status via Google Assistant voice command, but no open. I understand the potential security risk, but I should be able to opt in or out of my own decision. Especially when the intended use is for geofencing, so it would open when I'm putting up the street. It should give you the opening with an acceptance screen indicating the potential risks instead of just outright restricting the feature.

This does not integrate with ANYTHING other than your wifi network. They claim that it works with google assistant, but I have yet to figure out how to actually set that up. Google doesn't seem to know anything about MyQ or its existence and chamberlain actually has enough gall to ask you to pay a yearly subscription for that. To be fair they set up some sort of free trial subscription, but again google wants nothing to do with this thing (don't believe me, search for MyQ or Chamberlain in the device list for Google assistant).Again, product doesn't integrate with ANYTHING, so don't count on automation of any sort. For example, if you are driving home and want to open you garage, you need to park, unlock you phone, locate the app, open the app and then... hope that its your luck day cause you have about 80% chance of the door opening (worse if you have signal issues on your driveway). It is less frustrating and faster to have a manually operated door that requires you to come out of your the car, manually unlock with a key and pull open - fact, I've done that.

Since posting my original review, LeeAnna from Chamberlain reached out, and was great.  She took the time to try to troubleshoot the problem (which may turn out to have been a glitch in the door sensor, rather than a truly low battery (next few says will tell).  She was a breath of fresh air compared to my last customer service experience from them.Now that the battery in the door sensor issue seems to be resolved, all is working well, and the product is back to normal (I'll be following up with LeeAnna in a few days to see if it recurs, and if it does, I'm quite confident she'll make it right).

I'm not sure what the people did that had trouble with this.  It really is super simple!  I put the hub on a workbench in the garage, plugged it in and followed the step-by-step instructions in the app itself!  First the hub needed to connect to my 2.4g network.  No problem!  I selected the right network, gave it the password and was connected --- the same as if you were configuring your phone or computer to access.  Then the little sensor got paired with the hub by pressing the button on it a couple of times.  Final step - tell the app the brand of your garage door opener, hit the LEARN button on the garage door opener and let it do it's thing!I probably should mount the hub on the garage ceiling and plug it in the outlet that the garage door opener is plugged into - - only so that my wall outlet is open for other things!  Others I would be tempted to just leave the hub sitting on the bench or just stick it on the wall!

Unfortunately I didn't do my research well enough before buying to realize that in order for this device to work with the Google Assistant, you have to pay a small subscription fee. The fee is very trivial but the fact that Chamberlain would be so petty as to actually collect a fee for a WiFi garage door opener is just disgusting to me. On top of that, even if you did pay the fee, it doesn't seamlessly integrate with the assistant rather you would have to "talk to MyQ" to find out if your garage door is open, or to command it closed etc. There are workarounds to this but it's just extra steps you have to take for a product that is provided such a simple task. Because of this we hardly get any use out of this and it's completely not worth it. There are far better options out there that work well with the Google Assistant. I can't say how it works with Alexa because we don't use Alexa but I'd recommend staying away from this one.

I wanted to love this thing. It was going to make our lives so much easier. Well, starting the install process, i was left with taking well over an hour to get the door sensor to pair with the unit. I finally had to take the door sensor and hold it right up to the unit while TRYING to get it to pair. FINALLY after many times of trying, it paired.......only to have it need a factory restart due to being unable to change the WIFI it was connected to. not sure if i just got very unlucky, or this thing is just that bad, but it works, so far. I've had the door close, but reopened (i dont blame the unit, our garage door is a bit old and needs a few repairs) and the app just flat out said something like it was in motor mode only or something to that effect. I basically had to go out and close it from inside the garage. I guess i will wait and update in a month to see how bad this will be, but i hope it works without issue.
The Good:+ App seems to work well (android).

Finally pulled the trigger on prime day because the price was good. Arrived quickly but had some trouble with install. Called the support number and was on hold for more than 30 minutes before reaching someone. Isiah was great! He explained they were trying to unexpected resolve problems on their end and that was the reason for the high call volume and extended wait time. Isiah walked me through the setting up to get around the problem and corrected another problem that was located by overnighting a replacement part. I was frustrated initially but very happy with the service in the end.Helpful tip... have one myQ hub operating 2 Liftmaster 8500 openers in the same garage and it doesn’t appear that I needed any of the door sensors they show mount on the door. The app shows open/closed without the sensors mounted.

All in all it does what it’s supposed to do; it opens and closes the garage door via app. The app does a great job at showing you how to install the hub and pair it to your garage door opener but beyond that, it doesn’t teach you how to use the app to open and close the door and google assistant integration was awful. There was no Alexa integration option through the app either so I don’t even know if it works with Alexa. Due to the nature of the app complexity this gets 4 stars.

The install is super simple, download the app, use the app for instructions, very easy, I would guess that if your opener has the "Learn" or "Program" button on it, this will work with no issues. Works perfectly on a 20-year-old Genie Pro.The Application and Wifi set-up, again, seamless and very easy. Love the push notifications and love the Amazon Key feature, very nice!

Seems like it would have been a nice product, however, can’t get it to work. I even paid for a professional installer so I’m out an extra $100.Install seems straight forward, but for whatever reason the app on my iPhone XS won’t connect, I keep getting an error message. After that it says it will monitor the garage, but will not allow me to command for it to open and close.

*updated 5/21/20* after months of use, unit stopped working. Customer service was no help and just blamed (my working) door opener and passed me off to them... Would not replace the myQ unit. Wish I hadn't bought this, no wonder they were giving them away so cheaply!Got this unit at a bargain price but would be happy, hindsight, paying full price. Installation was easy and worked with my Chamberlain Liftmaster (which is an odd lift I needed for my low ceiling).

Easy to install but the Google Home integration is terrible. The device itself will not appear in Google Home but you can create Google Assistant integration that will give you exactly one thing... the ability to say to Google to close the garage door. That's it. On top of that, Chamberlain wants you to create an account that it wants you to pay for. Right now they are waiving the fee for a year but after that... who knows. What do you get for the subscription cost? Nothing other than if you don't pay it they will disable your device. There is no technical reason for them to be involved since the communciation is between your application and the device via your internet. This is just a way for Chamberlain to make people pay them more money... and likely to steal data about them. There are other solutions that don't try to extort their customers like Chamberlain is doing. If you have Z-Wave I'd recommend the Linear/2GIG GD00Z which is excellent. Still trying to determine the best WIFI one as an alternative to the MyQ one.

Hub in ceiling connected to WiFi with no problem.  I followed the iOS app instructions exactly - place door sensor where app suggested [upper corner of door].  The unit would not pare with Craftsman opener.  I tried multiple times to get it working and was ready to send it back.My last attempt was to move the door sensor into the center portion on the right half of door [closer to MyQ hub and garage door opener] and see if it would work.  Bingo - everything fell into place!!  Unit pared with opener instantly and has been working perfectly for weeks now and love the features.

I'm not sure what these other people are doing, but I had no issues getting this installed and working. I have a good wifi router, so maybe that's a big part of other peoples issues? If so, that's not this products fault. That's their fault for having crappy wifi coverage. If your wifi coverage is poor in your garage, then you'll need an access point to extend the range.The setup was pretty standard for this kind of product. You open the app, run through the steps 1 by 1. Don't rush, don't skip. Do exactly what it says to do and you shouldn't have any issues.

My son and I installed the MyQ while he was visiting us between Thanksgiving and Christmas. We followed the well-written directions and it was a piece of cake.  The unit works well and only time will tell how it holds up.  The one concern I have is the 3M adhesive that holds the garage door unit to the door.  Since my door is lightweight and not solid wood, the directions said to use the adhesive strips. Since the door moves from the vertical position to horizontal, my fear is the adhesive will lose its' grip over time and the unit will fall & break.  I know 3M makes a great adhesive so I'm expecting the best from it.  The remote works well using either my car universal or the Alexa on my phone.  I did have to re-train the car remote once the MyQ was installed (it must have lost the code when I was training the MyQ); but, that was an easy fix. Last year, when we were away traveling, our neighbor called to say our garage door had been open for three days.  Since all my power and hand tools are stored there, I was concerned.  Now, I can check on my iPhone and be assured my door is closed!

Although I like them, I'm weary of these kind of gadgets, so I read plenty of reviews before buying one, and this thing seemed to do it's job. After reading one review saying that you HAD to follow the instruction for an easy install, that's what I did and the install was super easy. The only hiccup was that it wouldn't sync with the opener. I finally had to call tech support and the guy said that I should erase all  my remotes so I could program this one and it worked fine after that. This should be put in the troubleshooting section in the app to avoid wasting time. I reprogrammed the other remotes after and this took a couple of minutes.The only thing that really annoys me/us is the loud beep on closing + light flashing. Can't turn this off since it's a "safety" feature. It would be nice to be able to use the light by itself also.

Update, Day 3: Received a system text @ 8am that my garage door was closed. Appears to have pinged servers or reset itself somehow. Error has cleared and app works again. Turned out okay because I was home and could visually see the door and manually click the wall button to close/open it. If I were out of town I would have to rely on a person to check it for me since it was showing in the app as open all night.Update, Day 2: "Close error" in MyQ app. Nothing in the way of the sensors. Followed steps to clear the error, but it remains. Cannot use the app to close the door. Already useless.

This item serves its purpose but it needs a lot of work. The Unit will open and close the garage door...most of the time. There are some kinks that need to be worked out like if you ever have a power outage, when your power comes back on you will have to run the garage manually before you can use the hub again. That's not helpful if you are out of town for a week and the power goes out for five minutes at any point. The same goes for internet service outage. If the internet drops for any amount of time, you must run the garage manually again before using the hub.  The online account and third party linking is terribly done. First it costs additional fees, then just logging in and out of the app and website account portal is painful.  This is a decent idea but I don't think it will be long before a universal garage remote maker comes along and actually does this right...

Easy setup and clever product.  I've had no issues with connectivity as I have a strong WiFi signal in the garage.  However, two big issues with this product so far which are causing the 3-star rating:1) Door open/closed notifications are often seriously delayed.  You get the Open Notification, but the Closed Notification sometimes shows up over 2 hours later?  Even during extremely busy times, Chamberlain's MyQ servers should be handle notification delivery in a matter of minutes.

This opener serves no purpose. It does not interlace with Alexa. It takes a lot of patience and several phone calls to technician to get this thing to work. Most of the time it does not work. He tells you the door is closed when it’s open and tells you it’s open when is close. Worked on it often on for four days with the help of tech before he even come close to operating.  The technician advised me it could be to the fact there could be an interference with the network,she listed all the items they’re supposed to be in the garage, washing machine dryer sprinkler timer lights LED lights. These items could cause an interference with the hub, Those items are what are in the garage. I gave this product to thumbs down. the only good thing that it was cheap so I can disconnect it and throw it in the trash

So there are a lot of mixed bag reviews on here regarding this product.  It went on sale and I decided to pick one up - at $30 it was worth a shot.  I called chaimberlain in advance to ask if it worked and they confirmed it would.  Once it arrived, I downloaded the app, followed the programming instructions and installation instructions and had it up in working in about 20 total minutes from the time I opened the package to completely installed.  I have mine mounted on the ceiling immediately next to the opener and it works great.  I just got it so there may be kinks -and I will update if that happens. So far, I'm very pleased.And a lot of questions and reviews state that it will not work on an Overhead door python2, but I will confirm that I have it setup and working on this opener.

UPDATE 08/28/2020 Assigned the myQ hub a static IP address on 7/21/2020. The myQ has worked perfectly since then. Raising review score from two to four stars.UPDATE  07/21/2020: The myQ has been installed for over 6 months. It is very convenient when it works. It worked flawlessly for the first couple of months. Since then it repeatedly has suffered sensor errors. I have relocated the hub and sensor but it the issue remains. I have worked with manufacturer but the device still has issues. I have a number of smart devices in my house. This is the only device that has problems.

Seriously, how did we function before this?? 1. Super easy installation. 2. Awesome for those times you leave home mindlessly, out of habit, and then wonder...did I close the garage door?? No more driving back to check. 3. Our garage is used for our golf cart, etc...we don't park in it....meaning our cars are always in the drive. You should NEVER leave a garage door opener in your car, in the drive (all someone has to do is break in your car, then they can open your garage!) We used to always carry our openers with us, such a pain!! Not anymore, not with this...we just open/close with our phones. We don't even need the openers anymore. Amazingly easy, beautifully reliable.Update, 1 year later: doesnt work worth a crap. Suddenly it just stopped working. I've uninstalled and reinstalled to no avail. Garbage.

This product has a very loud alarm that is the same volume and pitch as our smoke detectors.  Fire? Nope.  CO detected?  Nope.  Air raid?  Nope.  You chose to use your garage door.It turns what is otherwise a pretty decent product into a steaming pile of dog crap - only dog crap that screams at you.

Headline explains it all. I bought this on sale, but it went on a bigger sale a few weeks later...I can see why. This thing is over priced for what it is. The installation is super easy and the in-app instructions are very clear. I knew going in there was no Alexa integration (without a hack), but I expected the app that controls the door to be better/more reliable. First, there were 2 apps with the same exact name! They eventually retired one of them (the better working one!). Now for the lone app thats left, I sometimes hit the button and it works or doesn't work...I just hope for the best. I wish they could make it work more consistently. I'm doing it right outside my garage door when these problems happen and I have a Orbi 3000 whole home mesh system too...i know the wifi is strong all around. Another thing to note is the thing beeps very loudly when closing the garage door, as to warn folks. The garage door opener is already loud enough as a warning don't you think? This is a $20 device at most, but they charge way more. I'm too lazy to return it and look for something else as I don't use this that much.

I have been using the MyQ Smart Door Opener for two and a half months, and am very happy with it!  My wife and I have each left home, leaving the garage door open on occasion.  It is nice to be able to set event alerts such as the amount of time the garage door remains open.  It is really nice to be able to close it remotely from anywhere!  It's also handy to open it remotely if necessary.  At first I had WiFi issues and lost connectivity to MyQ every few days, and had to reboot my WiFi router.  I discovered other devices weren't connecting to WiFi either when that happened.  I tried a WiFi range extender and that didn’t help either.  My solution was to replace my old traditional WiFi router and range extender with a eero Pro 3-pack mesh router.  That product is amazing, and resolved all my WiFi issues.  I now have a strong WiFi signal that is almost as fast as a wired port, on each level of my home, and there have been zero interruptions.  I haven’t had MyQ connectivity issues since installing the eero!  The MyQ app for iOS works great, provides garage door status, and allows setting alerts by notification and email.  It also stores history of the garage door opening and closing cycles. Notifications show when the garage door is opened or closed by someone else. The MyQ Smart Door Opener is a reliable and affordable solution for monitoring and remotely operating your garage door, and offers peace of mind.

I bought this because a reviewer said it integrated with Google Home.  WRONG!It is very very easy to install.  Could not be any easier.  Well done on that front.  And it works just fine with the MyQ app.  But that is the ONLY way to get the garage door to work.  Even the Google assistant can only open the app.  And zero integration with Google Home.

I bought 2 units and 2 extra door sensors to control a total of 4 doors...after a couple tries and moving the main unit around it worked pretty well. The only issue I really would like to see is improvements within the app.  I do appreciate the alerts, and It works good if you are controlling one door, but if you need to open or close multiple you have to wait until one is finished before controlling another or the app freaks out and causes errors.  If you  are too impatient you get to set up all your doors again.
